This offering memorandum includes forward-looking statements, which are based on our current expectations and projections about future events. All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this offering memorandum including, without limitation, statements regarding our future financial position, risks and uncertainties related to our business, strategy, capital expenditures, projected costs and our plans and objectives for future operations, may be deemed to be forwardlooking statements. Words such as “believe,” “expect,” “anticipate,” “may,” “assume,” “plan,” “intend,” “will,” “should,” “estimate,” “risk,” and similar expressions or the negatives of these expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. By their nature, forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties because they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. Forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance. You should not place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements. In addition any forward-looking statements are made only as of the date of this offering memorandum and we do not intend, and do not assume any obligation, to update forward-looking statements set forth in this offering memorandum. You should interpret all subsequent written or oral forward-looking statements attributable to us or to persons acting on our behalf as being qualified by the cautionary statements in this offering memorandum. As a result, you should not place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements. Many factors may cause our results of operations, financial condition, liquidity and the development of the industry in which we compete to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forwardlooking statements contained in this offering memorandum. Factors that could cause such differences in actual results include: - challenging macroeconomic circumstances in the hotel industry or an economic downturn in Europe, particularly in the United Kingdom; - the effects of a prolonged economic downturn or period of weaker trading being exacerbated by our predominantly leasehold operating structure; - exposure of our operations to risks such as terrorism, political instability, events of military action, natural disasters, contagious diseases, pandemics, epidemics or acts of God; - seasonal fluctuations in customer demand; - operating in a highly competitive industry; - failure to maintain or enhance customer awareness of our brand; - our ability to respond to changes in consumer tastes, preferences and perceptions; - timing, budgeting and other risks that could delay our efforts to renovate our properties; - labor shortages or increased labor costs; - failure of our IT systems; - failure to comply with data protection legislation; - increase in the percentage of bookings through intermediaries, such as OTAs and increase in costs of such intermediaries; - failure to comply with regulatory requirements; ----- - failure to comply with environmental, health and safety laws and regulations; - the consequences of a major safety incident; - changes in laws governing our relationship with hotel employees; - challenges to our tax position or changes in tax laws; - inability to extend our leases; - increases of costs under our leases; - risk of disputes with our landlords; - risks of operating individual hotels at a loss and in exiting underperforming leases, management agreements and disposing of selected assets; - changes in tax laws and tax rates or challenges to our tax position; - risks related to having a number of hotels in our development pipeline which have not yet proven their commercial viability; - unsuccessful efforts to develop, acquire or invest in properties or enter into alliances and partnerships with third parties, or carry out developments in new markets; - our dependence on senior executives and key employees; - our dependence on relationships with our third-party suppliers and outsourcing partners; - insufficient insurance coverage; - our exposure to adverse litigation judgments or settlements; - difficulties with our franchise business; - changes to accounting standards; - risks in connection with the use of search engines and search engine marketing; - failure to protect our trademarks and intellectual property; and - other risks associated with the Notes and our structure as discussed under “Risk Factors.” We disclose important factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from our expectations in “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition _and Results of Operations.” Other sections of this offering memorandum describe additional factors_ that could adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. Moreover, we operate in a very competitive and rapidly changing environment. New risk factors emerge from time to time and it is not possible for us to predict all such risk factors. We cannot assess the impact of all risk factors on our business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements. Given these risks and uncertainties, you should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements as a prediction of actual results. -----

Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION Financial Information Included in this Offering Memorandum
Subsubsection Text: We present in this offering memorandum financial information of the Group. We have included in this offering memorandum: - audited consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 prepared in accordance with IFRS as applicable to the Group reporting under those standards as of December 31, 2020; - audited consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 prepared in accordance with IFRS as applicable to the Group reporting under those standards as of December 31, 2021; and - audited consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 prepared in accordance with IFRS as applicable to the Group reporting under those standards as of December 31, 2022 (collectively, the “Financial Statements”). Although there was a change in accounting framework between the audited consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 and as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021, there was no impact on recognition, measurement or disclosure in the audited consolidated financial statements of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 as a result of a change in framework. The standalone financial statements of the Parent Guarantor for the periods set forth above have not been included in this offering memorandum. Further, the independent auditors’ reports included in this offering memorandum refer to the standalone financial statements of the Parent Guarantor, which have not been included in this offering memorandum. The Financial Statements have been prepared on the basis of a calendar year from January 1 to December 31. For management reporting purposes we use a 5-4-4 week accounting calendar. This accounting method divides our fiscal year into four quarters, each comprising two periods of four weeks and one period of five weeks. We have adopted this accounting method because it allows us to manage our business on the basis of 52 weekly periods which consistently end on the same weekday. In order to align this method with our statutory annual accounting period, we make certain adjustments to our results in the last period of each fiscal quarter, in accordance with IFRS. We do not separately present the consolidated financial information of the Issuer because the Issuer has been formed solely for the purpose of facilitating the financing to the Group. As of the Issue Date, the Issuer will not conduct any operating activities, hold any assets, other than receivables under the Proceeds Loans (as defined herein), or have any material liabilities, other than the Notes and the Senior Facilities. Except as described below, we do not present in this offering memorandum any financial information or financial statements of the Issuer for the periods presented. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying our accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas in which assumptions and estimates are significant to our financial statements, are disclosed in our audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent Guarantor. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis _of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Critical Accounting Estimates and Judgments.”_ The financial information included in this offering memorandum is not intended to comply with reporting requirements of the SEC and will not be subject to review by the SEC. ----- Certain financial information in this offering memorandum has been rounded and, as a result, the figures shown as totals in this offering memorandum may vary slightly from the exact arithmetic aggregation of the figures that precede them.

Certain financial information, measures and ratios related thereto in this offering memorandum, including non-IFRS financial information, financial information presented on a non-IFRS basis, EBITDA (adjusted), EBITDAR (adjusted), EBITDA (adjusted) Margin, EBITDAR (adjusted) Margin and Rent Cover, Free Cash Flow and working capital movement (the “Non-IFRS Measures”) are prepared on a non-IFRS basis and not specifically defined under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. The calculation for the Non-IFRS Measures is consistent across periods presented in this offering memorandum. The most directly comparable IFRS measure to EBITDA (adjusted) and EBITDAR (adjusted) is profit/(loss) for the relevant period. Our Non-IFRS Measures are defined by us as follows: - “EBITDA (adjusted)” represents earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, and before rent phasing adjustment and non-underlying items and an adjustment to reflect accounting principles prior to our adoption of IFRS 16. For a description of non-underlying items and a reconciliation of EBITDA (adjusted) to profit/(loss) for the relevant period, see footnote 1 under “Summary—Summary Consolidated Historical and Other Financial Data.” - “EBITDAR (adjusted)” represents EBITDA (adjusted) before net external rent payable (before IFRS 16). For a reconciliation of EBITDA (adjusted) to EBITDAR (adjusted), see footnote 2 under “Summary—Summary Consolidated Historical and Other Financial Data”; - “EBITDA (adjusted) Margin” represents EBITDA (adjusted) divided by revenue; - “EBITDAR (adjusted) Margin” represents EBITDAR (adjusted) divided by revenue; - “Free Cash Flow” represents net cash flows from operating activities (before IFRS 16) minus capital expenditure; - “working capital movement” is stated before non-underlying movements, before giving effect to a rent phasing adjustment and before IFRS 16. - “Rent Cover” represents the ratio of EBITDAR (adjusted) to net external rent payable; - “before IFRS 16” represents what our results would have been under accounting principles prior to our adoption of IFRS 16; - “like-for-like,” with respect to RevPAR, compares the RevPAR in two or more periods on the basis of RevPAR generated by hotels that have been open for two years; - “net external rent payable” represents the net of rent receivable and rent payable (before IFRS 16) before the rent phasing adjustment. External rent payable (before IFRS 16) before the rent phasing adjustment reflects the rental amounts accrued adjusted for rent free periods by spreading such amounts over the period to the next rent review date (usually around five years) and recognizes the rent agreed during the CVA (for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021) in line with the actual rent paid; and - “rent phasing adjustment” represents the adjustment of the rent element of our EBITDA (adjusted) calculation, so that the benefit of rent free periods and the CVA rent reductions are spread over the full life of the lease. In many of our leases we receive a rent-free period at the beginning of the lease term. According to the straight lining of leases principle under IFRS prior to the application of IFRS 16, the benefit of this rent-free period is recognized gradually ----- over the life of the lease in our income statement as a deduction to the actual rent expense for each year, on a straight-line basis, over the life of each lease, with the unrecognized balance being held as an accrual on our balance sheet. Similarly, any credit relating to the rent reductions resulting from our CVA in 2020 is also recognized on a straight-line basis over the remaining life of each lease. As a result, our total rent expense under IFRS prior to the application of IFRS 16 does not reflect our cash payments of rent in any year. EBITDA (adjusted) for each year recognizes the portion of the rent-free credit attributable to that year as if such credit were applied on a straight line basis until the next rent review, normally five years, and recognizes the reductions resulting from the CVA in line with the actual rent paid in respect of each year. We believe the Non-IFRS Measures are useful metrics for investors to understand our results of operations, profitability and ability to service debt and because they permit investors to evaluate our recurring profitability from underlying operating activities. We also use these measures internally to track our business performance, establish operational and strategic targets and make business decisions. We believe EBITDA (adjusted) facilitates operating performance comparisons between periods and among other companies in industries similar to ours because it removes the effect of variation in capital structures, taxation, and non-cash depreciation, amortization and impairment charges, which may be unrelated to operating performance. We believe EBITDA (adjusted) is a useful measure of our underlying operating performance because it excludes the impact of items which are not related to our core results of operations, including certain one-off or non-recurring items. We believe EBITDAR (adjusted) is a useful measure of our underlying operating performance because it reflects our earnings prior to rent expense and excludes the impact of items which are not related to our core results of operations, including certain one-off or non-recurring items. The Non-IFRS Measures or comparable measures are frequently used by securities analysts, investors and other interested parties in their evaluation of companies comparable to us, many of which present EBITDA-related performance measures when reporting their results. EBITDA (adjusted) as presented in this offering memorandum differs from the definition of “Consolidated EBITDA” that will be contained in the Indenture. The Non-IFRS Measures have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our results or any performance measures under IFRS as set forth in our financial statements. Some of these limitations are: - not all of them reflect our cash expenditures and they do not reflect our future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on our debt; - they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay; - they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our consolidated income statement; - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations; ----- - some of the non-underlying items that we eliminate in calculating certain EBITDA-based measures reflect cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made; and - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Because of these limitations, the Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our IFRS results and using these Non-IFRS Measures only supplementally to evaluate our performance. See “Summary—Summary Consolidated Historical and Other Financial Data,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and our consolidated financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. For a description of how our Non-IFRS Measures are calculated from our consolidated results of operations and a reconciliation of the Non-IFRS Measures to our results for the period presented in this offering memorandum, see “Summary—Summary Consolidated Historical and Other Financial Data.”

Subsection Title: Unaudited Consolidated As Adjusted Financial Data
Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum includes unaudited consolidated as adjusted financial data which have been adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, as described under “Use of Proceeds.” The unaudited adjustments and the unaudited as adjusted financial data set forth in this offering memorandum are based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable and may differ materially from the actual adjusted amounts. The unaudited consolidated as adjusted financial data has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and do not purport to represent what our actual consolidated net senior secured debt and net third party indebtedness or cash interest expense would have been if the Offering had occurred (i) on December 31, 2022 for the purposes of the calculation of as adjusted net debt and (ii) on January 1, 2022 for the purposes of the calculation of unaudited consolidated as adjusted cash interest expense, nor do they purport to project our consolidated net debt and cash interest expense at any future date.

We have included other operating information in this offering memorandum, some of which we refer to as “key performance indicators,” including RevPAR, Occupancy, Average Room Rate and Rent Cover. We believe that it is useful to include this operating information as we use it for internal performance analysis, and the presentation by our business divisions of these measures facilitates comparability with other companies in our industry, although our measures may not be comparable with similar measurements presented by other companies. Such operating information should not be considered in isolation or construed as a substitute for measures prepared in accordance with IFRS. For a description of certain of our key performance indicators, see “Management’s Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Occupancy, ARR and RevPAR.”_ -----

This offering memorandum includes market share and industry information, which was obtained by us from industry publications and surveys, industry reports prepared by consultants, internal surveys and customer feedback. These include information published by Smith Travel Research (“STR”), Euromonitor International Limited (“Euromonitor”) and other third-party industry consultants and market research firms, or publicly available information from sources that are generally believed to be reliable, including information published by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP in its “UK Hotels Forecast 2022-2023” report published in November 2022 (“PwC Research”), which is publicly available and was not prepared for this offering or for the Issuer or the Parent Guarantor. These third-party sources generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but the accuracy and completeness of this information is not guaranteed and is based on significant assumptions. Although we believe these third-party sources are reliable, we do not have access to the facts and assumptions underlying the market data, statistical information and economic indicators contained in these third-party sources, and therefore are unable to verify such information and cannot guarantee its accuracy or completeness. In addition, various economic and other factors may cause actual results to differ from these projections. Certain forward-looking statements contained in such industry and market data may have been made prior to the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and have not been updated to account for the impact of such outbreak. There can be no assurance that such forward-looking statements would not have been materially different if the COVID-19 pandemic had been taken into account. See “Forward-Looking Statements.” Certain information in this offering memorandum represents our best estimate based upon information obtained from trade and business organizations and associations, consultants and other contacts within the industries in which we compete, as well as information published by our competitors. In particular, we prepared data (i) in respect of our market position based on information obtained from trade and business organizations and associations and other contacts within the industry in which we compete, (ii) in respect of industry trends based on our senior management’s business experience and experience in the industry and the local markets in which we operate and (iii) in respect of our operating performance based on our internal analysis (which has not been independently verified) of our own audited and unaudited information. Our estimates derived from this information may be incorrect and actual facts may differ from our estimates. The information we include regarding our market share in certain segments is based on revenues, hotels or rooms, as indicated. In addition, certain market data and statistics, including brand satisfaction and brand awareness, are generally based on market research, interviews and surveys conducted by us and third-party industry consultants, including YouGov and TripAdvisor. Such market research is largely based on sampling and subjective judgments by both the researchers and the respondents, and there is no assurance that the responses received are reflective of actual market conditions or sentiment. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding the industry or similar data presented herein, such data involves risks and uncertainties and is subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under “Risk Factors.” As far as we are aware and have been able to ascertain, no facts have been omitted that would render any such information inaccurate or misleading. Neither we nor any of the Initial Purchasers make any representation as to the accuracy or completeness of any such information in this offering memorandum. -----

We own or have rights to certain trademarks, trade names, brandmarks or service marks that we use in connection with the operation of our business. We assert, to the fullest extent under applicable law, our rights to our trademarks, trade names, brandmarks and service marks. Each trademark, trade name, brandmark or service mark of any other company appearing in this offering memorandum belongs to its holder. Solely for convenience, the trademarks, trade names, brandmarks and copyrights referred to in this offering memorandum are listed without the ™, ® and © symbols. We understand that there are three further operators of the Travelodge name in other regions around the world which are not connected with our Group: one based in North America, which operates and owns the rights in the USA and Canada; one based in Australasia, which operates in Australia and New Zealand; and one based in Asia which owns the rights to the Travelodge name in a number of territories in Asia, including Hong Kong, Malaysia, Pakistan and Singapore. -----

Founded in 1985, Travelodge is the second largest hotel brand in the United Kingdom based on number of hotels and number of rooms operated. We leased, franchised, managed and owned 595 hotels and approximately 46,000 rooms throughout the United Kingdom, Spain and Ireland as of December 31, 2022. We operate in the midscale and economy (“MS&E”) segment of the hotel market (as defined by STR) and are positioned as a budget operator, offering standardized, modern guest rooms at affordable prices to both business and leisure customers. Our purpose is to provide affordable travel for everyone and we aim to offer our customers the right balance of location, price and quality for their travel needs. As of December 31, 2022, we had brand recognition of 98% among the UK population (as measured by a YouGov brand tracking survey), driven by our long-standing market presence, wide geographic network and effective marketing initiatives. We operate multiple room formats across our hotels, namely our core standard rooms (43,442 in 595 hotels as of December 31, 2022), which include twin, family and accessible rooms, and our “premium economy” SuperRooms (2,319 in 64 hotels across the United Kingdom and Ireland as of December 31, 2022). We estimate that we attracted approximately 21 million customers in 2022, well exceeding our previous pre-COVID-19 pandemic peak of approximately 19 million customers in 2019. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 90% of our bookings were made through direct bookings, including approximately 80% made through our websites and approximately 10% through walk-ins, call centers and Groups. We operate a lean, low-cost operating model, with a relatively small support office and a high proportion of hourly paid team members in hotels. We employ approximately 12,000 people across our hotels and support offices, the majority of whom work in our hotels on hourly paid contracts. As of December 31, 2022, we operated 45,761 rooms in 595 hotels under the Travelodge brand. Within our largest market, the United Kingdom (excluding Northern Ireland), representing 98% of our total revenue in the year ended December 31, 2022, we operated 43,914 rooms (or 96% of total rooms) in 579 hotels, with 9,888 rooms (or 23% of UK rooms) in 79 hotels located in London and 34,026 rooms (or 77% of UK rooms) in 500 hotels located in regional areas across the United Kingdom. The majority of our hotels in the United Kingdom are leasehold. We also operate one hotel under a freehold and 10 hotels under management contracts in the United Kingdom. As of December 31, 2022, 1,226 rooms in 11 hotels were operated under franchise in Ireland and Northern Ireland, including a new central Dublin City Center hotel opened in 2022, and we operated 621 rooms in five hotels under leasehold in Spain. In early 2023, we opened our first new Spanish hotel in over ten years in Madrid. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue, EBITDA (adjusted) and RevPAR of £909.9 million, £212.9 million and £52.59, respectively, compared to £727.9 million, £129.1 million and £42.46 for the year ended December 31, 2019. Between the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2022, our revenue, EBITDA (adjusted) and RevPAR grew at a CAGR of 7.7%, 18.2% and 7.4%, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we had Occupancy and an Average Room Rate of 81.8% and £64.31, respectively, compared to 80.8% and £52.51 for the year ended December 31, 2019. ----- 93% of our UK revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022 was generated from accommodation, with the remainder from food and beverage and retail and other sales, including Wi-Fi, car parking and other guest services. The following map indicates the number of rooms that we operated by region as of December 31, 2022: The United Kingdom has one of the largest and most resilient hotel markets in the world, with the segment having already significantly recovered from COVID-19, and RevPAR growing at a CAGR of 4.4% over the last ten years (according to STR data, compared to 1.6% for real UK GDP (Source: International Monetary Fund (“IMF”)). Historically, the performance of the UK hotel industry has been closely correlated to the strength of the UK economy and of the local regions where hotels are situated. Even though the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted hotel operations and impacted the relationship between GDP and RevPAR, we believe that this will normalize in the future. Starting in 2021, the broader economy started to reopen and the breakout of the COVID-19 variant Omicron was contained by the successful rollout of the vaccine booster program. The dissipation of COVID-19 and related restrictions combined with the return of regular international travel were, according to Euromonitor, the driving forces behind the recovery of the lodging market in 2022. The hotel sector was well positioned to capture the post-COVID-19 rebound, benefiting from consumers’ pent-up demand for experiences and travel once the domestic economy re-opened. In particular, the MS&E segment has proven to be highly resilient throughout economic cycles, achieving a significant recovery from COVID-19, with revenues increasing 19.5% from 2019 to 2022. The MS&E segment is outperforming in the UK, with RevPAR growth above the total hospitality sector. Moreover, a recent consumer sentiment survey conducted by PwC in September 2022 showed that an increasing number of UK consumers expected to stay in less expensive accommodations, a development which could be positive for the MS&E segment. As such, we believe there are opportunities to grow the MS&E segment’s share of the UK market and, with a promising secured pipeline, we expect to maintain a regular program of new room openings. The UK hotel market remains relatively fragmented with a variety of local and international hotel operators and independents. We believe the fragmentation of the market presents opportunities for us to grow due to our strong brand recognition and scale. We benefit from high levels of customer satisfaction which we attribute to the quality of our offering and standardized work practices. We have made significant investments to strengthen the quality of our offering. We launched our “premium economy” room type, SuperRooms, which offers an enhanced specification, including a coffee machine, rain shower, choice of pillow and in-room hairdryer, iron and ----- ironing board. In early 2022, we launched a new design, which includes a series of non-capital intensive enhancements to transform the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés based on market feedback from extensive customer research. The new design seeks to drive higher demand and rate premiums by delivering a warmer and more welcoming environment with updated room features, including blackout curtains, USB charging points by the bed, a comfortable armchair and an upgraded bathroom. Our new design also delivers a new style bar café in our bar café hotels, offering a more flexible environment in which to eat, relax or work. In 2022, we upgraded 64 hotels and over 6,000 rooms (approximately 14% of the room estate) with our new design, with positive commercial and customer feedback, and we plan to upgrade over 4,000 rooms (approximately 10% of the room estate) in 2023. We plan to refurbish our entire estate over an approximately seven-year refit cycle. The investments in our estate are supported by a standardized and disciplined approach to operations, a lean operating model and efficient cost control, all of which drive profitability. We operate our hotels with a standardized room cleaning process, we have processes in place to monitor our customers’ experience, we provide in-person and online training modules for our employees and we rigorously benchmark our performance by using internal customer surveys and external benchmarking, such as TripAdvisor surveys. In addition, we continue to optimize our operating model by introducing technology to simplify, standardize and automate, including our investments in robot vacuums across our estate, which has helped to reduce the physical demands of the job for our employees, reduce our energy consumption and deliver cost efficiencies.

Subsubsection Title: Compelling long-term growth fundamentals in the resilient and underpenetrated budget hospitality market
Subsubsection Text: The United Kingdom has one of the world’s largest and most resilient hotel markets in the world with attractive characteristics. The UK hotel industry generated approximately £20 billion in room revenue in 2022, with approximately 16,392 hotels and 679,215 hotel rooms, according to STR data. Hotel travel by domestic guests has historically benefitted from strong business investment, employment levels, wages, consumer spending and consumer confidence in the UK. The UK hotel industry also benefits from a large number of travelers coming to the United Kingdom from other countries, for business travel and tourism, including for large events. Historically, the performance of the UK hotel industry has correlated with the strength of the UK economy generally, being closely related to GDP. Although the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted operations and impacted the relationship between GDP and RevPAR, we believe that this will normalize in the future. Nevertheless, the UK Hotel industry has been able to achieve substantial growth rates: as of December 2022, UK hotel room revenues have increased at a CAGR of 4.4% over the last ten years as compared to 1.6% for real UK GDP. ----- The chart below shows the long-term relationship between the change in real GDP growth and UK hotel RevPAR: _ Source: PwC Research November 2022 (UK Hotels Forecast 2022-2023)._ We are one of the two largest hotel brands in the UK MS&E segment, as defined by STR. Such segment has proven to be highly resilient throughout economic cycles, as in times of economic downturn, cost conscious businesses and leisure customers typically trade down and MS&E hotels are able to outperform the market average, which is particularly relevant in the current inflationary environment. RevPAR for the MS&E segment has recovered strongly from the COVID-19 pandemic. RevPAR for the MS&E segment in 2022 was 18% above RevPAR for the UK hotel market, which had only reached 2019 levels. Our UK like-for-like RevPAR for the year ended December 31, 2022 was approximately 10.9% ahead of the MS&E segment partly due to strong leisure demand and a rapid recovery in “blue collar” demand, with a more gradual recovery in “white collar” demand. While the current macro-economic environment creates uncertainty, the budget hotel segment has proven resilient, performing well during challenging economic periods relative to other segments and we expect the segment to benefit from a number of positive demand drivers, including continued staycation demand, consumers trading down to budget hotels, changes in working patterns, events and indirectly from inbound tourism as a result of the weak Pound. We believe that the MS&E segment is more resilient during times of economic hardship than other segments, in part, because cost conscious business and leisure customers trade down during those periods. Our revenue and RevPAR increased at a CAGR of 7.7% and 7.4%, respectively, between the year ended December 31, 2019 and the year ended December 31, 2022, while our EBITDA (adjusted) increased from £129.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to £212.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Alongside like-for-like RevPAR growth potential, we also believe there is further opportunity to increase the penetration of branded budget hotels in the United Kingdom. The MS&E segment of the UK hotel market accounted for approximately 37% of total hotel rooms compared to 60% in France (based on data produced by STR). As a result, we believe there are significant opportunities to grow the budget sector and the share of branded budget rooms in the United Kingdom. -----

Subsubsection Title: Leading market position driven by outstanding brand recognition and well invested network of hotels with proven and sustained market outperformance throughout economic cycles
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong position in the UK hotel market. We were the first budget hotel brand to launch in the United Kingdom and we had brand recognition of more than 98% among the UK population as of December 31, 2022, as measured by a YouGov brand tracking survey. Our modern hotels and standardized operational processes have allowed us to deliver high levels of customer satisfaction. As of December 31, 2022, our UK hotels had an average TripAdvisor score of four dots out of five, we received 287 TripAdvisor Traveler’s Choice Awards and 89% of our UK hotels were rated four dots or higher on Trip Advisor (from 88% in 2020 and growing or remaining stable every year since). This combination of customer satisfaction and operational discipline, has helped our UK like-for-like RevPAR growth to outperform the MS&E segment since 2015. We also have significant scale in the United Kingdom. We are the second largest hotel brand in the United Kingdom based on number of hotels and number of rooms operated, with 595 hotels and 45,761 rooms as of December 31, 2022 (of which 579 hotels and 43,914 rooms specifically in the UK). Our network is highly diversified with a strong presence throughout the UK, including a large footprint in London (9,888 rooms (or 23% of UK rooms) in 79 hotels as of December 31, 2022) and the rest of our hotels spread throughout other regional areas in the United Kingdom (34,026 rooms (or 77% of UK rooms) in 500 hotels as of December 31, 2022).

Subsubsection Title: Compelling guest proposition with attractive customer profile and advantageous business leisure mix
Subsubsection Text: We have a well invested estate, including six (including London Docklands Central, which replaced an existing hotel, and the Irish franchise in Dublin City Center) that have been newly opened since the beginning of 2022. Our rooms are designed with simplicity and cleanliness in mind, with upgraded facilities contributing to a positive customer experience. In early 2022, we launched a new design, which includes a series of non-capital intensive enhancements to transform the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés based on market feedback from extensive customer research. The new design seeks to drive higher demand and rate premiums by delivering a warmer and more welcoming environment with updated room features, including blackout curtains, USB charging points by the bed, a comfortable armchair and an upgraded bathroom, and a new style format bar café in our bar café hotels, offering a more flexible environment in which to eat, relax or work. In 2022, we upgraded 64 hotels and over 6,000 rooms (approximately 14% of the room estate) with our new design, with positive commercial and customer feedback, and we plan to upgrade over 4,000 rooms (approximately 10% of the room estate) in 2023. We plan to refurbish our entire estate over an expected seven year cycle, with interim works in selected hotels with heavier usage patterns. We have a multi-faceted customer base. For the year ended December 31, 2022, demand and customers spread across many unrelated sectors such as leisure, blue collar and white collar, and we estimate that approximately half our customers were business guests and half were leisure guests, with blue collar customers and white collar customers accounting for approximately 30% and 20%, respectively, of our UK customer base. We have offered business memberships to our business customers since 2016. In 2022, we had over 36,000 business membership sign-ups representing a 9% increase compared to 2019.

Subsubsection Title: Highly effective revenue management system with best in class direct distribution model and customer acquisition
Subsubsection Text: We use our direct distribution platform to sell rooms directly to our customers without an intermediary. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 90% of our bookings were made through direct bookings, including approximately 80% made through our websites and approximately 10% through walk-ins, call centers and Groups. Our leading direct distribution platform consistently delivers approximately 80% Occupancy across our hotels. We believe that large numbers of customers book directly with us due to our large-scale brand recognition, presence and simple, user-friendly website that is optimized for mobile use. We believe that our predominantly direct distribution platform gives ----- us greater access to our customers and more control over the booking process, while reducing our overall direct marketing and commission costs. Our pricing is centrally managed by a dedicated team, which uses an optimized revenue management system. We completed a major revenue management system upgrade in 2019, which in conjunction with investments in our data and analytics capability, has enhanced our strong performance after the COVID-19 pandemic. Our revenue management system uses all available information to forecast demand for each hotel and to optimize prices. Our rates are updated three times per day as internal and external factors change. We have a dedicated events team to monitor key events, such as large attendance concerts, sports events and cultural events, to set and adjust event specific pricing based on forecast demand. Our centralized team uses high-quality reporting, benchmarking and data analytics to monitor performance and adjust pricing in real time to further optimize the prices charged.

Subsubsection Title: Lean operating model, including significant proportion of CPI capped rent reviews, driving profitability and cash flows. Strong development pipeline with low upfront capex needs
Subsubsection Text: We operate a lean, low-cost operating model, with a relatively small support office and a high proportion of hourly paid team members in hotels. In the United Kingdom, excluding rent, depreciation and amortization, 36% of our operating costs were spent on hotel wages, 18% were spent on other property expenses, 10% were spent on cost of goods sold, including laundry and food and beverages, 10% on our central headquarters, 5% on marketing, 5% on maintenance, 3% on commissions and 13% on other costs) in the year ended December 31, 2022. We have implemented a range of measures to maintain the quality of our offering and reduce our costs. These measures include using predictive models to forecast occupancy at our hotels and align our employee rotas accordingly, optimizing internal processes to reduce the time it takes to complete certain tasks, training our housekeeping teams in multiple skill-sets to increase productivity and reduce personnel costs, and using a dedicated internal maintenance team to carry out routine maintenance. In addition, we have implemented new policies and technology to lower personnel costs, such as shorter hours with dedicated reception support. We also introduced robot vacuums across the estate, helping to reduce the physical demands of the job for our team members, reducing our energy consumption and delivering cost efficiencies. We have also continued to invest in automation of tasks with our Perfect Stay mobile application and energy efficiency measures in our hotels. In 2021, we brought a significant proportion of the remaining outsourced maintenance activity in-house, driving increased efficiency. We continue to selectively use outsourced services where greater service levels or opportunities to reduce costs are available, including certain complex maintenance work, certain aspects of information technology management and telephone bookings and support. As of December 31, 2022, we operated 568, or 95%, of our hotels under leases and we owned one of our hotels. The rest of our hotels are operated under management or franchise agreements. We lease almost all of our hotels through long-term arrangements with landlords, which allows us to expand our portfolio with low upfront capital expenditure, as the vast majority of the upfront construction costs of each hotel are funded by the freehold owner or developer. Development costs, which are incurred by our landlords, vary according to location and building configuration, but typically range between £80,000 and £90,000 per room excluding land (excluding certain locations such as London, where such costs are higher). New leases are normally 25 years, although properties in city centers and London are occasionally operated on terms of 35 years or longer. Most of our leases are subject to standard fiveyearly upwards-only rent reviews (some of which have upper and lower limits (“caps and collars”) on the amount the rent can increase at each review date), and are indexed against RPI or CPI, which allows for relative predictability of rental expenses. In January 2023, we completed a lease re-gear for 97 of our hotels (the “LXI Re-gear”). As part of the LXI Re-gear, rent reviews moved to a CPI + 0.5% per annum basis with caps and collars (4% per annum and 1% per annum, respectively) replacing the previously uncapped and uncollared RPI rent reviews. We expect to re-gear leases for an additional 25 hotels, subject to obtaining superior landlord consent, in the second quarter of 2023. As of December 31, 2022, we had entered into agreements to lease more than 22 new hotels with more than 2,100 rooms (our “secured pipeline”) and we expect to open eight hotels and approximately 600 rooms in 2023. In ----- the next few years, we plan to return to our normal hotel opening rate of 15 to 20 each year as market conditions improve. The overall UK rent cover for leases has increased from 0.88x in 2020 to 2.32x in 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2022, the rent cover profile (excluding central cost recharges (other than for maintenance costs) and before onerous provision releases) of our 560 UK hotels run under leases and open for at least twelve months was as follows: five hotels had rent cover of less than 1.0x (including two hotels in the Aberdeen market), 34 hotels had rent cover of 1.0x to 1.5x, 100 hotels had rent cover of 1.5x to 2.0x and 421 hotels had rent cover of more than 2.0x. The majority of our leases also have favorable extension rights and the average remaining term on our UK leases, excluding renewal rights and after giving effect to the LXI Re-gear that was completed in January 2023, was approximately 18 years as of December 31, 2022. The rent reviews for the leases across our estate are staggered over a five-year period to help smooth dramatic inflation increases. As a result of our tight cost control and low upfront capital expenditures on our leasehold properties, we had an EBITDA (adjusted) Margin of 23.4% in the year ended December 31, 2022, notwithstanding subdued UK hotel market growth and significant cost increases associated with wage cost growth that exceeded inflation. Our EBITDAR (adjusted) margins have also increased from 46.0% in the year ended December 31, 2018 to 49.2% in the year ended December 31, 2022.

Subsubsection Title: Comprehensive sustainability plan integrated into wider strategy
Subsubsection Text: We place a strong emphasis on safety and security, the environment, and our social responsibilities. Following extensive consultation with a wide range of stakeholders, we developed a comprehensive “Better Future” sustainability plan, which was launched in 2022. The plan will help us to improve focus and performance, and to share that progress transparently with our stakeholders. We firmly believe that sustainability has a critically important role to play in shaping the future of our business. For that reason, our Better Future sustainability plan is closely aligned with our mission, to provide affordable travel for everyone and integrated with our wider business strategy. Our Better Future plan is predicated on valuing our colleagues, customers and planet, and is underpinned by three pillars: (1) _Inclusive_ _— ensuring Travelodge is accessible, inclusive, and affordable to its colleagues and customers; (2) Caring _— creating a safe and healthy environment for our colleagues and customers, and ensuring their_ wellbeing; and (3) Conscious _— being conscious of the waste we produce, the energy and resources we consume, and our carbon emissions. In line with our Better Future plan, we implemented a number of energy reduction projects in 2022. To date, we have already generated an estimated annual reduction of 24 GWh through the installation of LED lighting in most of our hotels. We also installed smart heating and cooling controls at 133 of our hotels, bringing the total across the estate to 260 hotels. These controls reduce our heating electricity consumption by approximately 45% on average per hotel. Given new technology is also important to delivering our wider business plan, we now have air to water heat pump systems installed in five new hotels and plan to replace existing electric immersion hot water systems with air to water heat pump systems in two of our existing hotels in Carlisle and Ilford in 2023. This will enable us to test and understand the challenges of retrofitting these at existing hotels and to potentially implement a wider plan of replacements of other electric immersion hot water systems within our existing estate starting in 2024. Our goal is to become a net-zero business by 2050, including measuring and reducing our indirect scope 3 emissions. As part of our Better Future plan, we intend to become a net zero operator by 2050 for our direct emissions. We plan to achieve this through a general reduction of net energy consumption by leveraging technology such as efficient LED lighting in both common areas and guestrooms, smart heating and cooling controls, solar panels and replacing old, inefficient, electrically powered boilers for hot water, with new technology such as air to water heat pumps in conjunction with the decarbonization of the national grid set in UK law. We also plan to remove our need to use gas to heat water, and substitute this with other energy producing technologies. ----- For additional information on our key performance indicators relating to these principles, see “Business—Sustainability and ESG.”

Subsubsection Title: Experienced management team with solid track record of delivering operational and financial improvements
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong and experienced management team, with our Chairman and Chief Executive each having extensive experience in the hospitality and other sectors. On March 16, 2023, we announced the appointment of Aidan Connolly as Chief Financial Officer, and he started in this role on April 3, 2023. Mr. Connolly previously held executive positions at My Travel, Sodexo, Worldpay, Wilko and Alter Domus. Our senior management team benefits from a wide range of experience, including prior senior roles in the airline, retail and property industries. We have strong functional teams in sales and marketing, revenue management, property, IT and operations that are led by management members who have significant experience from working with major hospitality and other brands in the United Kingdom and other countries.

Subsubsection Title: Clear and significant opportunities for further growth
Subsubsection Text: We have identified near-term and highly actionable opportunities to unlock growth and improve the performance of our existing estate. We have begun to refurbish our entire estate over an approximately seven-year refit cycle, which we believe will enhance revenue performance and customer satisfaction. We believe we can grow our food and beverage offering by continuing to optimize our bar café performance through better aligning our offering with customer demand and by redesigning and simplifying our menu. As of December 31, 2022, we derived 36% of our food and beverage revenue from our bar café hotels. We have not advertised on television since the previous campaign ended in May 2016. We believe there is a strong strategic basis for brand building media investment to drive consideration of our brand, which will support our long-term RevPAR growth. We plan to continue to invest in numerous energy efficiency initiatives that provide long-term cost savings and support our goal to becoming a net-zero business. For example, in 2022, we installed smart temperature controls in 133 hotels and continued to benefit from the installation of smart temperature controls in 44 hotels installed in 2021. In addition, we have installed efficient LED lighting in most common areas and LED lighting is being installed in guestrooms. Under our low capital expenditure development model, when prospective hotel sites are identified, we work with the land owner and developers to agree a proposal and sign an agreement for lease. The developer then builds the hotel to our specifications and incurs the full costs of construction. Once the project is complete, we confirm that our requirements have been met. Subsequently, the developer typically sells the hotel building to a high quality institutional investor or private investor. We then begin operations and pay rent. We are typically responsible for all ongoing maintenance capital expenditure, which is primarily comprised of stamp duty and legal fees. We believe we can continue to use this model to grow our business.
Our key credit strengths include the following:

Subsubsection Title: Location: Extend Our Hotel Network and Strengthen Our Portfolio
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2022, we operated 45,761 rooms in 595 hotels under the Travelodge brand across the United Kingdom, Ireland and Spain. We aim to open hotels across the United Kingdom, Spain and potentially in other countries with sustainable low-cost demand. These locations include city centers, large towns and suburban markets, year-round leisure destinations, business parks and critical transport hubs. In the next few years, we plan to return to our normal hotel opening rate of 15 to 20 each year as market conditions improve. As of December 31, 2022, we had a secured pipeline of more than 22 new ----- hotels and more than 2,100 rooms. We expect to open eight hotels and approximately 600 rooms in 2023, and we intend to continue to explore opportunities to expand our hotel portfolio beyond our secured pipeline. We have the option to expand our operations in Ireland under our master franchise agreement. In addition, we believe expansion opportunities exist in Spain under our existing development model. In the UK, we have an in-house development team, supported by external third parties, that works with local developers and landlords to identify potential opportunities for new hotels. In addition, we use independent third-party hotel consultants to identify future potential locations suitable for our hotels in the UK and Spain. As part of our expansion strategy, we are targeting another 300 potential hotel locations across the UK that would be suitable for a Travelodge hotels. Based on our track record of new openings to date, we are confident that we can continue our expansion in the UK and internationally. Furthermore, while we don’t currently utilize a freehold model, we believe that a freehold model could present opportunities for growth as a largely untapped strategy, with the total capital requirement limited by the potential use of sale and leaseback transactions.

Subsubsection Title: Price: Offer Attractive Prices Supported by Predictive Data and Low-Cost Operations
Subsubsection Text: We aim to offer attractive prices using what we believe is a best in class yield management system and applying predictive analytics tools. Our price setting system uses data analysis to forecast demand, set pricing levels and monitor our rate of sale and our competitors’ pricing. Using exception reporting, our revenue team then adjusts the price points for each hotel individually where appropriate to optimize RevPAR, based on demand and competition. Our rates are updated three times per day and vary depending on hotel, room type, rate type, and stay date. We adjust our pricing to improve our RevPAR by aiming to strike the optimal balance between rate and occupancy. In the year ended December 31, 2022, over 84% of our bookings were made online through our websites. Digital sales channels are important to the growth of our business and we have already made significant changes to strengthen our presence, increasing website conversion and digital customer acquisition effectiveness. We continue to advance our digital strategy and evolve our customer targeting approach. This strategy is supported by a focus on maintaining low-cost operations through ongoing analysis of customer insight and optimizing key operational processes.

Subsubsection Title: Quality: Maintain Physical Asset Quality, Deliver Operational Consistency and Improve the Digital Journey
Subsubsection Text: We intend to further enhance our positioning as a distinctive brand by continuing to pursue initiatives which enhance our offer. In early 2022, we launched a new design, transforming the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés. We aim to continue our drive to improve the consistency of our customers’ experience. Our central operations team uses regular guest feedback to identify priority areas for operational change and we develop standardized processes for key areas within the hotel that directly affect the customer experience, such as room cleaning and breakfast service. We have also deployed a standard training program for our employees at each of our hotels which focuses on customer service and problem resolution, and we offer additional management development training for hotel managers. We have also continued to invest in automation tasks with our Perfect Stay mobile application, which we upgraded in 2020, and energy efficiency measures in our hotels. In 2021, we brought a significant proportion of the remaining out-sourced maintenance activity in-house, driving increased efficiency. We continue to selectively outsource certain functions and services where greater service levels or opportunities to reduce costs are available, including certain complex maintenance work, certain aspects of information technology management and telephone bookings and support. We have implemented significant improvements to our online platform to enhance the booking experience for our business customers. These include our Travelodge Business and Travelodge ----- Business Pay products designed with small and medium enterprises in mind but which also offer noteworthy efficiencies and benefits for larger companies. These products include a dedicated website for businesses, detailed reporting functionality to enable customers to manage their bookings and travel spend with greater ease, as well as a simplified and improved booking journey which also offers a discount on our most flexible rates. Additionally, we have partnered with a third-party provider to offer Travelodge Business Pay, an interest-free credit facility for our business customers. We aim to continue to strengthen our digital marketing activity, with targeted customer offers and buying of key search terms, appropriate digital display advertising and presence in appropriate meta-search engines.

Travelodge’s mission is to provide affordable travel for everyone and we aim to offer our customers the right balance of location, price and quality to suit their travel needs. We are pursuing the following strategies to achieve this goal:

On the Issue Date, the Issuer will issue the Notes offered hereby and use the gross proceeds of the Offering, together with cash on balance sheet, to (i) fund the Existing Notes Redemption, (ii) indirectly repay a portion of our capitalized interest on the Subordinated Shareholder Loans and (iii) pay related fees and expenses. The offering of the Notes and the use of proceeds therefrom, together with the entry into the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement, are referred to as the “Refinancing.” For descriptions of our current and anticipated indebtedness and certain financing arrangements, see “Capitalization,” “Description of Certain Indebtedness” and “Description of the Notes.”

The Issuer is TVL Finance plc, which was incorporated as a public limited company under the laws of Jersey on April 15, 2016, with registered number 121092. The Issuer’s registered office is located at 47 Esplanade, St Helier, Jersey JE1 0BD. The Issuer was incorporated solely for the purpose of facilitating the financing to the Group. As of the Issue Date, the Issuer will have no operations, material assets, other than receivables under the Proceeds Loans, or material liabilities, other than the Notes and the Senior Facilities.

GoldenTree Asset Management is a global asset management firm that specializes in opportunities across the credit universe in sectors such as high yield bonds, leveraged loans, private credit, digital assets, distressed debt, structured products, emerging markets, private equity and credit-themed equities. The firm was founded in 2000 with offices in New York, West Palm Beach, Charlotte, London, Dublin, Singapore, Sydney, Tokyo and Dubai, and over $49 billion in assets under management.
On March 16, 2023, we announced the appointment of Aidan Connolly as Chief Financial Officer, and he started in this role on April 3, 2023.

Subsubsection Title: Sponsor’s Acquisition of an Additional Stake in Anchor Holdings
Subsubsection Text: In December 2022, the Sponsor acquired all of the shares in Anchor Holdings held by funds advised by Avenue Europe International Management, L.P. and sub-advised by Avenue Europe Management, LLP, and in March 2023, the Sponsor acquired all of the shares in Anchor Holdings held by ELQ Investors VIII Limited, a wholly owned indirect subsidiary of Goldman Sachs Group Holdings (UK) Limited.

On January 27, 2023, we completed a lease re-gear for 97 hotels, which, among other things, moved rent reviews to a CPI + 0.5% per annum basis with caps and collars (4% per annum and 1% per annum, ----- respectively) replacing the previously uncapped and uncollared RPI rent reviews. We expect to re-gear leases for an additional 25 hotels, subject to obtaining superior landlord consent, in the second quarter of 2023. See “Business—Operating Models—LXI Re-gear.”

Subsubsection Title: Partial Repurchase of Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes
Subsubsection Text: In January 2023, we repurchased a principal amount of £15.8 million Existing Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes in the open market.

Our revenue was £180.0 million through March 22, 2023, an increase of approximately 30% compared to the same period in 2022. In 2023, our revenue and like-for-like RevPAR were positively impacted by strong leisure demand, including public events, continued strong “blue collar” demand and improving “white collar” demand, with corporate mid-week central London demand recovering but partly offset by national rail strikes. In addition, the first quarter of 2022 was heavily impacted by Omicron restrictions. London hotel performance was significantly ahead of 2022, reflecting the slower recovery experienced in 2022. Regional hotel performance was ahead of 2022, with strong leisure and “blue collar” demand. Forward bookings were positive but with limited visibility. Based on the STR Total Room Inventory methodology currently in place, we performed in line with the MS&E segment compared to 2022 due to strong first quarter 2022 comparables in London and the refit of two of our large central London hotels. Our 2023 performance was 40% ahead of 2019 levels and we outperformed the MS&E segment compared to 2019. As of March 22, 2023, we had cash and cash equivalents (before quarterly rent and other month end payments) of approximately £227 million. _The unaudited preliminary interim financial information for the periods presented above is based on management’s assessment of trading conditions and our internal management accounts which have not been prepared in accordance with IFRS. The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured by the Collateral. The Collateral will also secure obligations under the Senior Facilities provided under the Senior Facilities Agreement, as well as certain hedging obligations and certain other indebtedness on a super senior basis. In the event of an enforcement of the Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such collateral only after lenders under the Senior Facilities, the counterparties to certain hedging arrangements and the creditors for other indebtedness permitted to be secured on a super priority basis have been repaid in full. (4) In connection with the Refinancing, on or about the Issue Date we intend to enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement, which provides for the £50.0 million Revolving Credit Facility and the £30.0 million Letter of Credit Facility. While the Revolving Credit Facility is not currently expected to be drawn as of the Issue Date, we will have issued letters of credit in an aggregate amount of £27.2 million under the Letter of Credit Facility as of the Issue Date. See “Description of Certain Indebtedness—Senior Facilities _Agreement.” The Senior Facilities are secured by the same Collateral that will secure the Notes offered hereby._ (5) The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Parent Guarantor and certain of the Parent Guarantor’s subsidiaries located in England and Wales. Each of the Notes Guarantees will be a general senior obligation of the respective Guarantor. The Guarantors also guarantee on a senior secured basis any obligations of the borrowers under the Senior Facilities Agreement. Each of the Notes Guarantees will rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future debt of the applicable Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Notes Guarantee and will rank _pari passu in right of payment with such Guarantor’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including the applicable Guarantor’s obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement. (6) The Issuer is a public limited company which, as of the Issue Date, will have no operations, material assets, other than receivables under the Proceeds Loans, or material liabilities, other than the Notes and the Senior Facilities. The Issuer’s ability to service its debt, including the Notes, depends entirely on the ability of HoldCo 6 to make the payments owed by it under the First Proceeds Loan. HoldCo 6 is not obliged to make any other payments or capital contribution to the Issuer other than those required under the First Proceeds Loan. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees.” (7) The Issuer will on-lend the proceeds from the Offering to HoldCo 6 pursuant to the First Proceeds Loan Agreement. See “Use _of Proceeds” and “Description of the Notes.”_ (8) As of December 31, 2022, the Guarantors held 98.3% of our total consolidated assets (excluding brand intangible assets, deferred tax assets and net consolidation adjustments due to the adoption of IFRS 16). As of December 31, 2022, the non-Guarantor subsidiaries of the Parent Guarantor had no debt outstanding. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees—The Notes will be _structurally subordinated to the liabilities of non-Guarantor subsidiaries.”_ (10) Our main operating company is Travelodge Hotels Limited. As of December 31, 2022, Travelodge Hotels Limited held 99.8% of our total consolidated assets and in the year ended December 31, 2022, generated 98.4% and 98.5% of our revenues and EBITDA (adjusted), respectively. Travelodge Limited was formed for the purpose of protecting the Travelodge brand, by preventing other companies from being incorporated with the same name. Travelodge Limited is a dormant entity that has share capital (and net assets) of £1. -----

Ranking of the Notes ........................................** The Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth under “— _Security”;_ - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes (including obligations under the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations); - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Parent Guarantor that are not Guarantors, including obligations to their trade creditors. Accordingly, each of the Notes Guarantees of a Guarantor will: - be a general senior obligation of such Guarantor, secured as set forth under “Description of the Notes—Security”; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes ----- Guarantees (including obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations); - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes Guarantees; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Group that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes Guarantees, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness (if any); and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Parent Guarantor that are not Guarantors, including obligations to their trade creditors. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on Validity _and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ The Notes Guarantees will be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description of _the_ _Notes—Notes_ _Guarantees—Notes Guarantees Release.”_ Security .............................................................** The obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Indenture are expected to be secured as of the Issue Date by a first-priority security interest in: (i) the shares of the Issuer; (ii) the bank accounts and receivables of the Issuer under the First Proceeds Loan; and (iii) material assets of each Guarantor under an English law debenture including the Second Proceeds Loan, in each case, subject to the agreed security principles (collectively, the “Collateral”). The Senior Facilities will be secured by firstranking liens granted over the same assets ----- (subject to certain exceptions) that secure the Notes. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, however, proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral will be required to be applied to repay indebtedness outstanding under the Senior Facilities, certain hedging obligations and certain other indebtedness entitled to be secured on a super senior priority basis in priority to the Notes. The validity and enforceability of the security will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the _Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ The Intercreditor Agreement will provide that as a contractual matter among the Senior Secured Creditors (as defined in “Description of Certain _Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement”), the_ Notes will be secured on a pari passu basis with the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations and will be treated as such for purposes of proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral. The Collateral securing the Notes and the Senior Facilities may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes— Withholding Taxes.”

GBP Notes .........................................................._ Prior to     , 2025, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the GBP Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption, plus a “make whole” premium, as described under “Description _of_ _the_ _Notes—Optional _Redemption—GBP Notes.”_ Prior to     , 2025, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the GBP Notes with the net proceeds of one or more specified equity offerings, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption, provided that at least 50% of the aggregate principal amount of the GBP Notes (excluding any additional GBP Notes issued) remains outstanding after the redemption (unless all GBP Notes are redeemed substantially concurrently). In addition, prior to     , 2025, up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the GBP Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional GBP Notes issued) may be redeemed in each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof. The Issuer may redeem all or part of the GBP Notes at any time on or after     , 2025, at the redemption prices described under “Description _of_ _the_ _Notes—Optional_ _Redemption—GBP Notes,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and_ additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Euro Notes at any time on or after     , 2024, at the redemption price described under “Description _of the Notes—Optional Redemption—Euro Notes,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and_ additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See “Description of the _Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control ............................................** If the Issuer experiences a change of control, the holders of the Notes will have the right to require the Issuer to offer to repurchase the Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a certain consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such an event. See “Description _of the Notes—Change of Control.”_ Certain Covenants ...........................................** The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Issuer and the restricted subsidiaries of the Issuer to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; ----- - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. Accordingly, we cannot assure you as to the development or liquidity of any market for the Notes. Furthermore, the Notes will not have registration rights under the Securities Act. Governing Law .................................................** The Indenture, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be governed by the laws of the State of New York. Ratio of EBITDA (adjusted) to as adjusted cash interest expense ............................................. x (1) EBITDA (adjusted) represents earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, and before a rent phasing adjustment and non-underlying items and an adjustment to reflect accounting principles prior to our adoption of IFRS 16. EBITDA (adjusted) is not defined by IFRS. We believe EBITDA (adjusted) is a useful metric for investors to understand our results of operations and profitability because it permits investors to evaluate our recurring profitability from underlying operating activities. We also use this measure internally to establish forecasts, budgets and operational goals to manage and monitor our business, as well as evaluating our underlying historical performance. We believe EBITDA (adjusted) facilitates operating performance comparisons between periods and among other companies in industries similar to ours because it removes the effect of variation in capital structures, taxation, and non-cash depreciation, amortization, impairment charges, non-underlying items and rent phasing adjustment which may be unrelated to operating performance. We believe EBITDA (adjusted) is a useful measure of our underlying operating performance because it excludes the impact of items which are not related to our core results of operations, including certain one-off or non-recurring items. For a description of the limitations of EBITDA (adjusted) as an analytical tool, see “Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Financial and Operating Information.” ----- The following table reconciles our profit/(loss) for the period, our most directly comparable measure under IFRS, to EBITDA (adjusted):
