Listing of any of the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange does not imply that a public offering of any of the Notes in the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man has been authorized. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange for comparable issuers, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting of the Notes from the Official List of the Exchange or another listing exchange may have an adverse effect on a holder’s ability to resell Notes in the secondary market and may give rise to withholding tax (in the event the Notes are not listed on a “recognised stock exchange” within the meaning of Section 1005 of the UK Income Tax Act 2007).

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.
Subsubsection Text: We expect that one or more independent credit rating agencies will assign credit ratings to the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed herein and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Certain covenants and events of default will be suspended if we receive investment grade ratings.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the date of the Indenture, the Notes receive an investment grade rating of Baa3 or better by Moody’s and BBB- or better by S&P, and no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing, then beginning that day and continuing until such time as the Notes are no longer rated investment grade by either ratings agency, certain covenants will cease to be applicable to the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of _Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.”_ At any time when these covenants are suspended, we will be able to, among other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay cash dividends and redeem subordinated indebtedness without restriction, each of which may conflict with the interests of holders of the Notes. There can be no assurance that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating if achieved will be maintained.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant clearing system to exercise any rights and remedies.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be issued in registered global form. The Regulation S Global Notes and the Rule 144A Global Notes (each as defined herein) will be deposited, on the Issue Date, with a common depositary for the accounts of Euroclear and Clearstream and registered in the name of the nominee of the common depositary. Ownership of beneficial interests in the Global Notes (the “Book-Entry Interests”) will be limited to persons that have accounts with Euroclear and/or Clearstream or persons that hold interests through such participants. Book-Entry Interests will be shown on, and transfers thereof will be effected only through, records maintained in book-entry form by Euroclear and Clearstream and their participants. ----- Owners of beneficial interests in the Global Notes will not be entitled to receive definitive Notes in registered form, except under the limited circumstances described in “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form— _Definitive Registered Notes.” So long as the Notes are held in global form, holders of Book- Entry_ Interests will not be considered the owners or “holders” of the Notes. The nominee of the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream will be considered the sole holder of the Global Notes. Accordingly, if you hold a Book-Entry Interest, you must rely on the procedures of Euroclear or Clearstream, as applicable, and on the procedures of the participant through which you hold your interest to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of Notes under the Indenture governing the Notes. Payments of any amounts owing in respect of the Global Notes (including principal, premium, interest and additional amounts, if any) will be made by the Issuer to the paying agent for the Notes (the “Paying Agent”). The Paying Agent will, in turn, make such payments to the common depositary (or its nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream. After payment to the common depositary or its nominee for Euroclear and Clearstream, we will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or other amounts to the holders of Book-Entry Interests. Unlike the holders of the Notes themselves, holders of Book-Entry Interests will not have the direct right to act upon the Issuer’s solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes. Instead, if you hold a Book-Entry Interest, you will be permitted to act only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear or Clearstream, as applicable. The procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies may not be sufficient to enable you to vote on a timely basis. Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture governing the Notes, unless and until Definitive Registered Notes (as defined herein) are issued in respect of all Book-Entry Interests, if you hold a Book-Entry Interest, you will be restricted to acting through Euroclear or Clearstream. The procedures to be implemented through Euroclear or Clearstream may not be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: You may face currency exchange risks by investing in the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The GBP Notes are denominated and payable in Pounds. The Euro Notes are denominated and payable in Euros. If you measure your investment returns by reference to a currency other than Pounds or Euros, investment in Notes of that relevant currency entails currency exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the Pound or Euro relative to the currency you use to measure your investment returns, caused by economic, political and other factors which affect exchange rates and over which we have no control. Depreciation of the Pound or the Euro against the currency by reference to which you measure your investment returns would cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which you measure your investment returns. There may be tax consequences for you as a result of any currency exchange gains or losses resulting from your investment in the Notes. You should consult your tax advisor concerning the tax consequences to you of acquiring, holding and disposing of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Investors in the Notes may have limited recourse against the independent auditors.
Subsubsection Text: The Financial Statements included in this offering memorandum have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, independent auditor, as stated in their reports appearing herein. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP is a member of The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales. In accordance with guidance issued by The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, each of the independent auditors’ reports of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP states: “this report, including the opinions, has been prepared for and only for the company’s members as a body in accordance with ----- Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the UK Companies Act 2006 and for no other purpose. We do not, in giving these opinions, accept or assume responsibility for any other purpose or to any other person to whom this report is shown or into whose hands it may come save where expressly agreed by our prior consent in writing.” You should understand that in making these statements, the independent auditors confirmed that it does not accept or assume any liability to parties (including the Initial Purchasers of the Notes and you) other than to the respective company and its members as a body with respect to such reports and to the independent auditors’ audit work and opinions. The SEC would not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection with an offering of securities registered under the Securities Act, or in a report filed under the Exchange Act. If a U.S. court (or any other court) were to give effect to such limiting language, the recourse that you may have against the independent auditors based on their reports or the consolidated financial statements to which they relate could be limited.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The interests of our shareholders may conflict with the interests of the holders of the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: Our Sponsor has and will continue to have, directly or indirectly, the power to affect our legal and capital structure, as well as the ability to elect and change our management and to approve other changes to our operations and to control the outcome of matters requiring action by shareholders. The interests of our shareholders may conflict with the interests of holders of the Notes. Our Sponsor and investment funds advised by it are in the business of making investments in companies and may have an interest in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings, joint ventures or other transactions that, in their judgment, could enhance their equity investment or cause us to make dividend payments (subject to limitations in the Indenture) or other distributions or payments to them as shareholders, even though such transactions might involve risks to you as holders of the Notes. Conversely, our Sponsor may have an interest in not pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, joint ventures and other transactions that could enhance our cash flow and be beneficial to you. Moreover, our Sponsor and investment funds advised by it may, from time to time, acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly, or indirectly, with us. Furthermore, our Sponsor may sell all or any part of its shareholding at any time or may look to reduce their holding by means of a sale to a strategic investor, an equity offering or otherwise.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Notes Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: If the stated principal amount of the Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount greater than or equal to a statutorily defined “de minimis amount,” then the Notes will be considered to be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued with OID, then, in addition to the qualified stated interest on a note, a U.S. Holder (as defined in “Tax Considerations— _Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations”) would generally be required to include_ such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues on a constant yield basis for U.S. federal income tax purposes in advance of the receipt of cash payments to which such income is attributable and regardless of the holder’s method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. See “Tax _Considerations—Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.”_ -----

_An investment in the Notes involves risk. You should carefully consider the following risks, together with other information provided to you in this offering memorandum, in deciding whether to invest in the Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below could be detrimental to our financial performance. If these events occur, the trading price of the Notes could decline, we may not be able to pay all or part of the interest or principal on the Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment. Additional risks not currently known to us or that are presently deemed immaterial and that are not discussed or described in this offering memorandum may also harm us and affect your investment._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Founded in 1985, Travelodge is the second largest hotel brand in the United Kingdom based on number of hotels and number of rooms operated. We leased, franchised, managed and owned 595 hotels and approximately 46,000 rooms throughout the United Kingdom, Spain and Ireland as of December 31, 2022. We operate in the midscale and economy (“MS&E”) segment of the hotel market (as defined by STR) and are positioned as a budget operator, offering standardized, modern guest rooms at affordable prices to both business and leisure customers. Our purpose is to provide affordable travel for everyone and we aim to offer our customers the right balance of location, price and quality for their travel needs. As of December 31, 2022, we had brand recognition of 98% among the UK population (as measured by a YouGov brand tracking survey), driven by our long-standing market presence, wide geographic network and effective marketing initiatives. We operate multiple room formats across our hotels, namely our core standard rooms (43,442 in 595 hotels as of December 31, 2022), which include twin, family and accessible rooms, and our “premium economy” SuperRooms (2,319 in 64 hotels across the United Kingdom and Ireland as of December 31, 2022). We estimate that we attracted approximately 21 million customers in 2022, well exceeding our previous pre-COVID-19 pandemic peak of approximately 19 million customers in 2019. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 90% of our bookings were made through direct bookings, including approximately 80% made through our websites and approximately 10% through walk-ins, call centers and Groups. We operate a lean, low-cost operating model, with a relatively small support office and a high proportion of hourly paid team members in hotels. We employ approximately 12,000 people across our hotels and support offices, the majority of whom work in our hotels on hourly paid contracts. As of December 31, 2022, we operated 45,761 rooms in 595 hotels under the Travelodge brand. Within our largest market, the United Kingdom (excluding Northern Ireland), representing 98% of our total revenue in the year ended December 31, 2022, we operated 43,914 rooms (or 96% of total rooms) in 579 hotels, with 9,888 rooms (or 23% of UK rooms) in 79 hotels located in London and 34,026 rooms (or 77% of UK rooms) in 500 hotels located in regional areas across the United Kingdom. The majority of our hotels in the United Kingdom are leasehold. We also operate one hotel under a freehold and 10 hotels under management contracts in the United Kingdom. ----- As of December 31, 2022, 1,226 rooms in 11 hotels were operated under franchise in Ireland and Northern Ireland, including a new central Dublin City Center hotel opened in 2022, and we operated 621 rooms in five hotels under leasehold in Spain. In early 2023, we opened our first new Spanish hotel in over ten years in Madrid. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue, EBITDA (adjusted) and RevPAR of £909.9 million, £212.9 million and £52.59, respectively, compared to £727.9 million, £129.1 million and £42.46 for the year ended December 31, 2019. Between the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2022, our revenue, EBITDA (adjusted) and RevPAR grew at a CAGR of 7.7%, 18.2% and 7.4%, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we had Occupancy and an Average Room Rate of 81.8% and £64.31, respectively, compared to 80.8% and £52.51 for the year ended December 31, 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: General Economic Conditions and Growth in Our Sector of the Hotel Market
Subsubsection Text: As the second largest hotel brand in the United Kingdom, our business depends on customer demand for our rooms and the related services that we provide, which are in turn dependent on the general state of the hotel and travel industry, primarily in the United Kingdom, where we had 568 leasehold hotels (excluding hotels we operate under management contracts) and one owned hotel as of December 31, 2022. Our UK hotels (including fees received under management contracts relating to 11 hotels we operate and the Irish franchise) accounted for £895.3 million, or 98.4%, of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022. In addition, we have five leased hotels in Spain, which accounted for £14.7 million, or 1.5%, of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022. Performance in the hotel industry in the locations where we operate is closely linked to global, European and UK economic growth. In particular, the UK hotel market performance is linked to economic growth and growth of RevPAR is generally closely aligned with GDP growth over time. Even though the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted hotel operations and impacted the relationship between GDP and RevPAR, we believe that this will normalize in the future. Other macro-economic factors influence demand for hotel accommodation and/or increase costs for our hotels, particularly increases in inflation or interest rates, consumer spending and consumer confidence, business investment, employment levels, wages (including the National Living Wage), and public spending on temporary accommodation. Inflation particularly has increased generally in 2022, with ----- notable increases in the unit costs of both electricity and gas. The impact of the Ukraine conflict has contributed to this increase and could cause sustained inflationary pressures if not concluded in the short term. The cost of living crisis, driven by high levels of inflation, also has the potential to impact demand and consumer choices. However, the budget sector where we operate has historically demonstrated a strong resilience and has the potential to overcome adverse macro-economic factors, with customers usually trading down to budget hotels during difficult economic periods. We operate in the MS&E segment which in 2022 generated £4.9 billion of revenue from 247,062 rooms, which accounted for 36% of the total number of rooms in the UK, according to STR. We are positioned as a budget operator, offering standardized, modern guest rooms at affordable prices to both business and leisure customers. The largest operators in the MS&E segment are us and our main competitor, Premier Inn. The MS&E segment has historically demonstrated strong growth and resilience throughout economic cycles, with the top two hotel brands by number of hotels and number of rooms in the United Kingdom both positioned in the MS&E segment, according to STR. In addition, budget operators have historically shown stronger resilience than the wider industry across the hotel cycle. Following a decline in 2020 and 2021 due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK hotel industry recovered strongly during 2022 despite the inflation and cost of living crisis, benefiting from increased consumer demand across both leisure and business. According to STR, the MS&E segment showed the strongest recovery across the UK market and ended 2022 significantly ahead of 2019, which had a positive impact on our results of operations in 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: During the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted the UK and the global economy and strained the hospitality industry due to travel restrictions and stayat-home directives in place at various times during the period, resulting in cancellations and significantly reduced travel around the world. The reduction in travel resulted in the complete and partial suspensions of hotel operations in many of the areas where our hotels are located, including the closure of the overwhelming majority of our hotels from March 24, 2020, to July 4, 2020. As such, the COVID-19 pandemic had a material impact on our results for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021. In 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, we implemented a Company Voluntary Arrangement (“CVA”) in the UK that was approved by creditors on June 19, 2020. The CVA provided for (i) no planned hotel closures and no permanent rent reductions, (ii) a temporary reduction in rents in 2020 and 2021, (iii) £240 million in the form of a new £60 million credit facility, £40 million of additional capital, the use of significant cash reserves (approximately £100 million prior to the COVID-19 outbreak) and the drawdown of our existing £40 million revolving credit facility, and (iv) cash conservation including operating and capital cost savings and the utilization of the available government COVID-19 related support. In the UK, we accessed government support in the form of the Job Retention Scheme and the retail, hospitality and leisure business rates holiday. The rent reductions under the CVA ended at the end of 2021 and we paid full rents in 2022. The CVA completed on January 19, 2023. The CVA agreement includes an excess cumulative EBITDA landlord rent payment clause, whereby if the cumulative EBITDA (adjusted) from 2020 to 2022 is more than £200 million, two-thirds of the excess will be payable to landlords, adjusted as appropriate for the impact of any subsequent agreements made with individual landlords on their individual payments. As a result of our performance in 2022, we are required to make a one-off payment of approximately £13 million in April 2023. Following the lifting of restrictions in the UK on May 17, 2021, demand and revenue gradually improved to return to pre-COVID-19 levels by the end of September 2021. This trend continued and was driven predominantly by higher rates but also higher occupancy levels resulting from (i) strong ----- domestic leisure demand, (ii) a rapid recovery in “blue collar” business demand and (iii) gradual recovery in “white collar,” together resulting in quick recovery and performance above 2019 levels by early February 2022. We also benefited from strong event demand, including the Commonwealth Games and the Queen’s funeral. The gradual recovery from COVID-19 has been experienced in the MS&E segment as a whole, which has now achieved and surpassed 2019 figures. The MS&E Segment revenues have increased by 19.5% from 2019 to 2022, driven by greater pricing power and higher occupancy numbers as a result of the easing of COVID-19 restrictions. ARR and Occupancy figures are also higher than 2019 by 16.9% and 1.5%, respectively, as of December 31, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: During a typical year not impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, our business is seasonal in nature. We have high occupancies in the summer, and tend to perform strongest when there is both strong business and leisure demand. Our occupancy is lowest, and we may incur a loss, during the first quarter of each year, where there is softer general business demand and lower levels of leisure demand, especially in seasonal resorts. Our first quarter revenue is also negatively affected when Easter occurs in the first quarter of the year due to fewer business travelers, though this is partially offset by an increase in leisure travelers. An early Easter also generally sees less leisure demand than one later in the second quarter, but this is also impacted by the weather and proximity to other bank holidays and half term holidays. Our results are also affected by periods of abnormal, severe or unseasonal weather conditions, including natural disasters such as floods and other adverse weather and climate conditions. Mild weather may increase occupancy levels in leisure destinations, particularly during peak travel season. Weather also typically affects our energy costs, which increase when there is abnormally severe or prolonged cold or hot weather.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In early 2022, we launched a new design, which includes a series of non-capital intensive enhancements to transform the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés based on feedback from extensive customer research. The new design seeks to drive higher demand and rate premiums by delivering a warmer and more welcoming environment with updated room features, including blackout curtains, USB charging points by the bed, a comfortable armchair and an upgraded bathroom. Our new design also delivers a new style bar café in our bar café hotels, offering a more flexible environment in which to eat, relax or work. In 2022, we upgraded 64 hotels and over 6,000 rooms (approximately 14% of the room estate) with our new design, with positive commercial and customer feedback, and we plan to upgrade over 4,000 rooms (approximately 10% of the room estate) in 2023. We plan to refit the entire estate over the next seven-year refit cycle, with interim works during this cycle in selected hotels. These strategic investments have are having a positive impact on both customer and commercial metrics, including RevPAR. We also made various investments as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Our number one priority is the safety and security of our customers and teams. In 2020, we created TravelodgeProtect+, a program of cleaning and social distancing measures, designed to keep our guests and teams safe and give everyone peace of mind. The program was developed by a dedicated cross-functional hygiene strategy team after discussion with our peers and industry group bodies, such as the UK Hospitality Association. We also continued our investments in cleaning with the roll-out of robot vacuums across the estate, helping to reduce the physical demands of the job for our team members, reducing our energy consumption and delivering cost efficiencies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Improvements in Our Revenue Management Process
Subsubsection Text: We have improved our yield management process, which is intended to grow RevPAR through optimizing pricing and occupancy. Our pricing is centrally managed by a dedicated team, which uses ----- an optimized revenue management system. We completed a major revenue management system upgrade in 2019, which in conjunction with investments in our data and analytics capability, has enhanced our strong performance after the COVID-19 pandemic. Our revenue management system uses all available information to forecast occupancy at each hotel and to optimize prices. Our rates are updated three times per day as internal and external factors change. We have a dedicated events team to monitor key events, such as large attendance concerts, sports events and cultural events, to set and adjust event specific pricing based on forecast demand. Our centralized team uses high-quality reporting, benchmarking and data analytics to monitor performance and adjust pricing in real time to further optimize the prices charged. We believe that optimized revenue management will continue to positively contribute to our performance. We have implemented significant improvements to our online platform to enhance the booking experience for our business customers. These include our Travelodge Business and Travelodge Business Pay products designed with small and medium enterprises in mind but which also offer noteworthy efficiencies and benefits for larger companies. These products include a dedicated website for businesses, detailed reporting functionality to enable customers to manage their bookings and travel spend with greater ease, as well as a simplified and improved booking journey which also offers a discount on our most flexible rates. Additionally, we have partnered with a third-party provider to offer Travelodge Business Pay, an interest-free credit facility for our business customers. We aim to continue to strengthen our digital marketing activity, with targeted customer offers and buying of key search terms, appropriate digital display advertising and presence in appropriate meta-search engines.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our business benefits from strong brand recognition in the United Kingdom, our primary market. We continue to maintain strong brand recognition through a wide range of marketing activities, including extensive investment in direct sales, digital marketing, traditional offline marketing and an ongoing presence in the media, both nationally and locally. The majority of our investments in marketing are focused on strengthening our digital presence, which supports more than 80% of our bookings. We seek to maintain our presence in organic search through paid investments in digital advertising and sponsored links where appropriate. We conduct most of our marketing efforts through digital, online advertising and search engine optimization in order to appeal to customers who are searching for and comparing hotel options online. We plan to continue to focus on developing our web offer and driving conversion through better user experience, with an emphasis on attracting business customers and repeat stays. We expect to continue to adopt an optimized marketing approach, using traditional, digital and direct marketing as appropriate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from our existing hotels is primarily affected by Occupancy and ARR. Both Occupancy and ARR are strongly correlated to general economic conditions, the strength of the travel industry and the supply of and demand for hotel accommodation in a specific market. We believe that the strength of our brand, the geographic distribution of our hotel portfolio and our different operating models allow us to diversify risks related to specific hotels in our portfolio. In order to react appropriately to developments in our local markets, we continuously monitor Occupancy, ARR and RevPAR of our hotels. _Occupancy_ Occupancy is the quotient of the total number of Room Nights sold during a specified period divided by the total number of rooms available for each day during that period. Occupancy measures the utilization of our hotels’ available room capacity. We use Occupancy to measure demand at a specific hotel or group of hotels in a given period at the rates charged. Demand is principally driven by the need ----- for general business travel, leisure travel including the propensity of people to visit friends and relatives, special events such as sporting events, concerts and conferences, as well as other events in the hotel’s proximity. Occupancy is affected by the rate strategy we deploy, which sets prices, and by the supply of hotel rooms in the area surrounding each of our hotels, and increases in hotel room supply, which can increase competition and make it more difficult to achieve high Occupancy. _Average Room Rate (ARR)_ Average Room Rate is the quotient of total room revenues for a specified period divided by total Room Nights sold during that period. There is usually a positive correlation between rate and Occupancy, and we aim to maximize RevPAR with our revenue management strategy. _RevPAR_ RevPAR is the product of the Average Room Rate for a specified period multiplied by the Occupancy for that period. RevPAR does not include non-room revenues, which consist of ancillary revenues generated by a hotel property, such as food and beverage, as well as Wi-Fi, parking and other guest services. We use RevPAR to identify trend information with respect to room revenues of comparable properties and to evaluate hotel performance on a regional basis. RevPAR is a commonly used performance measure in the hotel industry. We believe that a change in RevPAR is a reliable indicator of a change in revenue from our hotels because RevPAR takes into account both ARR and Occupancy. However, RevPAR changes that are driven predominately by changes in Occupancy have different implications for overall revenue levels and incremental profitability than do changes that are driven predominately by changes in ARR. For example, assuming the same room rates and variable operating costs, including housekeeping services, utilities and room amenity costs, increases in Occupancy at a hotel would lead to increases in room revenues compared to lower levels of Occupancy and such increased Occupancy may also result in increased ancillary revenues, including food and beverage. In contrast, changes in ARR typically have a greater effect on margins and profitability, because rates increase while variable operating costs remain relatively stable. We regularly review our occupancy and rate forecasts, which have been stress tested with plausible but conservative changes to assumptions including cost of living crisis and other macroeconomic shocks.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: A significant portion of our other operating expenses (before IFRS 16) is rent expense, which is primarily determined by our ability to negotiate favorable terms under new lease agreements, the rental prices in the region in which our hotels are located and the predominantly RPI related growth rates applied to our existing leases. We typically rent our hotels under 25 to 35 year triple net leases with various landlords. Typically, new leases have a six month initial rent free period and an upwards only rent review every five years, most commonly linked to RPI growth with caps and collars. We also receive rental income on some sites where we sublet space to third parties. A small portion of our rent expense results from a variable rent component under our leases which is tied to the revenue level we generate at the relevant leased hotel. In the last three years our rent expenses were impacted by the CVA implemented in 2020 as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The CVA completed on January 19, 2023. In January 2023, we also completed the LXI Re-gear, which, among other things, moved rent reviews to a CPI + 0.5% per annum basis with caps and collars (4% per annum and 1% per annum, respectively) replacing the previously uncapped and uncollared RPI rent reviews. In addition, the unexpired lease terms on 97 hotels were extended by a weighted average of nine years and the parties agreed “rent-smoothing” of the hotels on a site by site basis, to ensure that each hotel has a robust standalone Rent Cover. We expect to re-gear leases for an additional 25 hotels, subject to obtaining superior landlord consent, in the second quarter of 2023. See “Business—Operating Models—LXI Re-gear.” In 2023, we estimate rent costs of approximately £250 million to £260 million, reflecting the impact of rent reviews and new hotel openings in 2022 and 2023. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Operating Expenses (Other than Rent, Depreciation/Amortization and Non-underlying items)
Subsubsection Text: In parallel with significant investments to improve the quality of our rooms and expand our offering, we have also made investments aimed at streamlining operational delivery, improving the quality of service and in turn the overall customer experience. Operating expenses (excluding rent, depreciation/amortization and non-underlying items), have increased principally due to the increase in occupancy levels in 2022 and the impact of inflation, increasing employee costs following the end of the UK government’s job retention scheme in 2021 and the increase in the National Living Wage, the end of the hospitality business rates holiday in Wales and Scotland and of government support grants, increased costs associated with increased trading such as utilities, maintenance and transaction fees, higher marketing spend and increased costs from new and maturing hotels. In 2023, we estimate cost inflation of approximately 7% to 8%. This reflects the significant inflationary pressures facing the wider UK economy, as well as some specific price increases impacting laundry and food and beverage and the impact of our hedged energy position. One of the largest components of our operating expenses is employee costs and our financial results are impacted by our ability to manage these costs. Our employee base varies throughout the year and we employ approximately 12,000 employees on varying hours and contracts. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we employed 7,832 average fulltime equivalent employees in our UK operations and 75 in our international operations. The large majority of our employees work in our hotels. We estimate that approximately 87% of our employees are paid hourly. In April 2023, the National Living Wage in the UK increased from £9.50 per hour to £10.42 per hour for all workers over 23 years old. We offer the over 23 year old National Living Wage as a minimum to staff of all ages. We expect to continue to closely manage our employee costs. In response to the increased National Living Wage we have and we continue to focus on ways to improve our efficiency, including more effective rostering and greater use of an appropriate full-time/part time mix in each hotel, and in common with many other hotel businesses, we will seek to pass on elements of the cost increase to customers in the form of higher charges. We seek to control our employee costs by forecasting our needs based upon anticipated business volume, including Occupancy, and food and beverage sales. Recently, employee costs have increased due to our efforts to improve our central office operations and the service quality in our hotels. At our hotels, we have invested in extra bar café staff hours, additional training and increased staff hours in some hotels to improve quality, while, at our central office, we have grown our sales, digital, marketing, revenue management and operational support teams. During 2022 we continued to focus on cost management, including implementing procurement best practice, following the recruitment of a new procurement function. Increasing inflation caused increases in expenses, such as cost of sales, including laundry and food and beverage. We started commercial negotiations to manage increases in several significant operating costs, including energy, food and beverage and linen. To help manage energy costs, we use flexible energy contracts which allow the fixing of electricity and gas prices through the term of the contract. We renewed our energy contracts in early 2023 and we entered into hedging agreements for the majority of the year under a purchasing framework to minimize risk and maximize the opportunity for future price reductions. In 2023, we estimate energy costs to increase from 2022 levels by high single digit millions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our future growth depends in part on our ability to expand our hotel portfolio by opening new hotels. We base our decision to open new hotels on the expected financial performance of the hotel, using a detailed appraisal of the local market characteristics, local competition and an analysis of historic performance of comparable hotels within our network. We do not typically build our own hotels and therefore we do not typically take on direct development or planning risk. Instead, we partner with a wide range of developers, including large scale developers and regional companies, who build our hotels and then transfer them to us in the manner of a leasehold ----- obligation. We agree a rental period and fee and oversee progress on development to ensure the site meets our specifications. The majority of the capital spent is for the account of the developer, and our rent obligations usually only begin once a hotel is successfully handed over to us. Development costs vary according to location and building configuration, but typically range between £80,000 and £90,000 per room excluding land (excluding certain locations such as London, where such costs are higher). Assets typically take two to three years from entering our pipeline to opening, with the first year or so being primarily planning and the second year or so consisting of construction and fit-out. However, currently build cost issues and the unavailability of financing have caused delays. Newly opened hotels usually breakeven within the first year and take around two years to fully mature, affecting our profitability during this initial ramp-up period. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we opened six new hotels (including London Docklands Central, which replaced an existing hotel, and the Irish franchise in Dublin City Center). As of December 31, 2022, we had entered into agreements to lease more than 22 new hotels with more than 2,100 rooms (our “secured pipeline”). We currently expect to spend approximately £5 million in development costs in 2023 related to new hotel openings. We believe that our secured pipeline is strong, and that our management team has a proven track record of delivering new hotels on budget. New openings could be delayed due to unforeseen events, including weather and labor issues and resource constraints in the construction industry. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We have a _number of hotels in our development pipeline, which may experience delays in opening, may not be successful or may not realize the anticipated benefits.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We consider the following factors, which are discussed further below, as the key factors affecting our results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022: - general economic conditions, competition and growth in our sector of the hotel market; - the COVID-19 pandemic; - seasonality and weather; - renovation and improvements of our hotels; - improvements in our revenue management process; - brand awareness and marketing; - occupancy, ARR and RevPAR; - rent expense; - expenses (other than rent); and - new hotel openings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Our revenues are mainly derived from providing budget hotel accommodation and other goods and services to guests. For the year ended December 31, 2022, for example, hotel accommodation accounted for 93% of our UK revenue (excluding hotels we operate under management contracts). Revenue is measured at fair value of the consideration received or receivable and represents the amount receivable for goods and services supplied to customers in the normal course of business, net of trade discounts and VAT. A portion of our revenue from providing accommodation is derived through prepaid room bookings, all revenue from accommodation is recognized when customers check-in at our hotels, over the period of stay. We also derive revenue from food and beverage sales, car parking, Wi-Fi and vending machines. Under management agreements, we provide hotel management services. Base and incentive management fees are typically charged. Base management fees are typically a percentage of total hotel revenues and incentive management fees are generally based on the hotel’s profitability. Both are treated as variable consideration. Base management fees are recognized as the underlying hotel revenues occur. Incentive management fees are recognized over time when it is considered highly probable that the related performance criteria will be met, provided there is no expectation of a subsequent reversal of the revenue. Under franchise agreements, we receive franchise fees, which are recognized as the underlying hotel revenues occur and a fixed fee per reservation is recognized on the booking date.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Rent consists of rent payable to third-party landlords net of rent receivable. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Other income mainly consists of compensation for room damage and smoking fines.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Operating expenses consist of cost of goods sold, employee costs, audit fees and other operating expenses. Cost of goods sold includes laundry and linen, consumables in rooms, the cost of food and beverages sold and the costs associated with retail and other income, such as Wi-Fi, vending and car parking. These typically increase in line with occupancy levels and price inflation. Employee costs comprises wages, salaries and benefits. Other operating expenses includes property costs such as utilities, business rates, service charges and insurance; banking charges; IT systems costs; marketing costs such as our digital advertising and commissions; and maintenance and other operating costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation, amortization and impairment is applied to our (i) lease premiums, which are amortized on a straight line basis over the full duration of each lease, (ii) IT software, which is amortized on a straight line basis over its expected useful life (“UEL”) of three years, (iii) brand (goodwill), which is reviewed annually for impairment, (iv) freehold buildings, which are depreciated to their estimated residual values (“ERV”) over a period of up to 50 years, (v) leasehold buildings, which are depreciated to their ERV over 50 years, or where shorter, their remaining lease periods, (vi) fixtures and fittings, which are depreciated on a straight line basis between three to five years and (vii) finance lease assets, which are depreciated over their UEL or, where shorter, the term of the relevant lease. Depreciation includes charges in respect of the right of use of the assets. Depreciation is provided on cost in equal annual instalments over the estimated remaining useful lives of the assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: (Loss)/Profit on disposal of assets primarily relates to loss on disposal of the London Docklands hotel and profit on disposal of assets where break clauses were instigated as a direct result of the CVA.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance costs include interest on our bank loans, finance fees, interest on obligations under finance leases and unwinding of discount on provisions. It also includes the interest on our investor loan, which is rolled up into the principal and not due for payment until the loans expire or terminate. The IFRS 16 notional interest rate refers to the estimated incremental borrowing rate calculated on a lease by lease basis as of the date of implementation of IFRS 16 or inception of the lease, if later. Following the adoption of IFRS 16 from January 1, 2019, finance costs includes notional interest charges relating to future lease liabilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance income includes interest on our bank deposits.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Non-underlying items relate to non-recurring, one-off items and represent material, non-recurring items which our management considers not representative of the continuing performance of our business. Non-underlying items are identified on a case-by-case basis for each financial period. In the periods under discussion, non-underlying items primarily included: financing costs relating to the early settlement on a term loan facility, reassessment of provisions and legal and advisors’ fees and management incentives relating to the restructuring of the Group’s debt and other exceptional corporate activities and share based payment charges, CVA payments to compromised landlords, and impairment of intangible assets and property plant and equipment and right of use assets. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) These items are presented before non-underlying items. _Revenue_ Revenue increased by £350.1 million, or 62.5%, from £559.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £909.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the lifting of the work from home guidance, which resulted in quick performance recovery. This trend continued and was driven predominantly by higher rates but also higher occupancy levels benefiting from strong domestic leisure demand and a rapid recovery in “blue collar” business demand together with a more gradual recovery in “white collar” corporate demand. We also benefited from a reduced VAT rate for the hospitality sector of 12.5% in the first quarter of 2022. In the year ended December 31, 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic impacted the business heavily. In early 2021, restrictions throughout the UK mandated that guests were only allowed to stay in hotels for work, education or other legally permitted reasons but not for leisure purposes. We started 2021 with 354 UK hotels open and trading, with closures in the first couple weeks which reduced this number to 293 by January 15, 2021 and we ended January with 295 open hotels. Certain hotels were opened through February, March, April and May with all available hotels open by May 15, 2021. Following the lifting of restrictions in the UK on May 17, 2021, demand and revenue gradually improved to the end of September 2021. Like-for-like UK RevPAR for the year ended December 31, 2022 improved by 59.2% compared to the year ended December 31, 2021. ----- _Operating Expenses_ Operating expenses increased by £162.1 million, or 54.0%, from £300.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £462.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the higher trading levels in 2022 as all hotels reopened progressively in 2021 following the easing of lock-down restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic. Costs were also impacted, to a lesser extent, by inflationary pressures. The cost of goods sold increased by £21.3 million, or 79.2%, from £26.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £48.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase resulted primarily from higher laundry costs, which were driven by higher occupancy levels and supplier price increases, and lower food and beverage costs in 2021 due to hotel closures, extended bar café closures and inflation. Employee costs increased by £55.6 million, or 36.9%, from £150.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £206.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily due to higher trading in 2022 levels as all hotels reopened progressively in 2021 following the easing of lockdown restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic, the end of the UK government’s job retention scheme, the impact of the increase in the National Living Wage in the UK and recruiting additional staff in our new and maturing hotels. We made claims of approximately £21 million in respect of the UK government’s job retention scheme for the year ended December 31, 2021. In addition, in 2022, employees (other than senior management) received cost of living vouchers, at a gross cost of £4.0 million. Other operating expenses increased by £85.2 million, or 69.4%, from £122.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £208.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was primarily driven by the end of the hospitality business rates holiday in Scotland and Wales that resulted in an approximately £1.0 million benefit in 2022 relative to a £21.0 million benefit in 2021, government support grants of £9.7 million in 2021 compared to approximately £1.8 million received in the first half of 2022, higher marketing spend, increased costs associated with all hotels being open in 2022 compared to 2021, such as utilities and maintenance, higher transaction fees due to the level of bookings and increased costs from new and maturing hotels. _Net External Rent Payable_ Net external rent payable (before rent phasing adjustment) decreased by £0.8 million, from £4.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to £3.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Net external rent payable (before rent phasing adjustment and before IFRS 16) increased by £56.0 million, or 31.2%, from £179.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £235.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to the benefit of rent reductions in the year ended December 31, 2021 of approximately £55 million. The impact of new hotels, together with upwards only rent reviews predominantly linked to RPI, also contributed to the increase in rent payable. _Loss on Disposal of Fixed Assets_ Loss on disposal of fixed assets was £7.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This was related to the write off of assets as a result of our hotel refurbishment program. _Depreciation/Amortization_ Depreciation increased by £9.6 million, from £144.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to £154.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Depreciation (before IFRS 16) remained relatively stable at £40.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 compared to £41.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Depreciation is driven mainly by ongoing investment in maintenance and the refurbishment of our estate, including health and safety measures, energy ----- efficiency projects, IT hardware and new hotel openings. Increases due to the restart of our ongoing hotel refurbishment program were offset by the impairment of a small number of assets in 2021. Amortization decreased by £1.2 million, from £5.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to £3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Amortization (before IFRS 16) decreased by £1.9 million, or 11.8%, from £16.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £14.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Amortization is driven mainly by historical lease premiums, investment in IT systems (which result in an intangible asset) and new hotel openings. The decrease was primarily due to the impairment of a small number of assets in 2021 and fully written down computer software. _Finance Costs_ Finance costs before interest on investor loan increased by £14.8 million, from £227.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to £242.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Finance costs before interest on investor loan (before IFRS 16) increased by £6.0 million, or 13.6%, from £44.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £50.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was predominantly due to higher interest payments on floating rate debt, which were driven by an increase in SONIA rates in 2022, partially offset by lower interest on our revolving credit facility due to the full repayment of drawings in May 2022 and the repayment of our term loan facility in October 2022. Investor loan interest remained relatively stable at £20.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 compared to £20.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Finance Income_ Finance income comprising interest on loans to related parties and bank interest increased by £1.7 million, from £0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £1.9 million for the year end December 31, 2022. The increase was due to an increase in cash balances and the base rate during the year ended December 31, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) These items are presented before non-underlying items. _Revenue_ Revenue increased by £275.4 million, or 96.8%, from £284.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £559.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Revenue was heavily impacted by the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 and 2021. In early 2021, restrictions throughout the UK mandated that guests were only allowed to stay in hotels for work, education or other legally permitted reasons but not for leisure purposes. We started 2021 with 354 UK hotels open and trading, with closures in the first couple weeks which reduced this number to 293 by January 15, 2021 and we ended January with 295 open hotels. Certain hotels were opened through February, March, April and May with all available hotels open by May 15, 2021. Following the lifting of restrictions in the UK on May 17, 2021, demand and revenue gradually improved to the end of September 2021. Trading decline during the festive period at the end of the year and cancelations increased on the news of the Omicron variant and the work from home guidance in the UK. Conversely, we experienced strong revenue growth at the beginning of 2020, before COVID-19 began to impact the business from March 2020, with the first closure of our UK hotels mandated from March 24, 2020. The first lockdown restrictions eventually concluded on July 15, 2020. While 51 hotels remained open during the first lockdown period as part of our commitment to support NHS workers, key workers and vulnerable groups, these contributed negligible net income and overall revenues throughout the second quarter of 2020 were virtually eliminated. A phased reopening of our hotels was undertaken during a six to seven week period from early July 2020 to the middle of August 2020, with the effects of the pandemic continuing to heavily impact the third quarter of 2020. The imposition of new tiered restrictions throughout the UK in the final quarter of 2020 resulted in further hotel closures, with guests only allowed to stay in hotels for work, education or other legally permitted reasons but not for leisure purposes. ----- Like-for-like UK RevPAR for the year ended December 31, 2021 improved by 99.0% compared to the year ended December 31, 2020. _Operating Expenses_ Operating expenses increased by £72.2 million, or 31.7%, from £228.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £300.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. We managed costs tightly in 2021 as the impact of the pandemic continued, resulting in a lower ratio of operating expenses relative to revenue compared to the year ended December 31, 2020. The cost of goods sold increased by £9.4 million, or 53.7%, from £17.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £26.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase resulted primarily from higher laundry costs driven by higher occupancy levels. Employee costs increased by £37.0 million, or 32.6%, from £113.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £150.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to a reduction in the use of the UK government’s job retention scheme, the impact of the increase in the National Living Wage and recruiting additional staff in our new and maturing hotels. We made claims of approximately £21 million in respect of the UK government’s job retention scheme for the year ended December 31, 2021. Other operating expenses increased by £25.8 million, or 26.6%, from £97.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £122.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to higher trading levels in 2021, increased costs from new and maturing hotels and reduced hospitality business rates benefits in 2021 of approximately £21 million, partially offset by savings from cost efficiency programs and business grants of approximately £10 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Net External Rent Payable_ Net external rent payable (before rent phasing adjustment) increased by £1.3 million, from £2.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to £4.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Net external rent payable (before rent phasing adjustment and before IFRS 16) increased by £49.3 million, or 37.9%, from £130.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £179.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. In 2020, rent was paid in full for the first quarter before the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Significant rent reductions were agreed for the remainder of 2020 (totaling approximately £85 million) and 2021 (totaling approximately £55 million) as part of the CVA in June 2020. While we continued to benefit from the rent reductions in 2021, these reductions were lower than those in 2020. The impact of new hotels, together with upwards only rent reviews predominantly linked to RPI, also contributed to the increase in rent payable. _Depreciation/Amortization_ Depreciation decreased by £2.4 million, from £146.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to £144.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Depreciation (before IFRS 16) increased by £4.6 million, or 12.6%, from £36.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £41.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase resulted primarily from ongoing investment in the refurbishment of our estate, including health and safety measures, energy efficiency projects, IT hardware and new hotel openings. Amortization increased by £0.4 million, from £4.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to £5.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Amortization (before IFRS 16) remained relatively stable at £16.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to £16.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Amortization was driven primarily by historical lease premiums, investment in IT systems (which result in an intangible asset), new openings, partially offset by reductions resulting from the impairment of historical lease premiums for a small number of assets in 2020. ----- _Finance Costs_ Finance costs before interest on investor loan increased by £19.0 million, from £208.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to £227.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Finance costs before investor loan interest (before IFRS 16) increased by £8.5 million, or 23.8%, from £35.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £44.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 primarily due to the impact of increased debt incurred in 2020 to fund liquidity in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Bond interest costs increased by £4.1 million following the issuance of the £65 million Existing Senior Secured Fixed Rate Notes in December 2020, partially offset by the impact of the decrease in LIBOR. We drew £40 million under our existing revolving credit facility in March 2020 and £30 million in June 2020 under a new super revolving credit facility put in place in April 2020. We then drew £60 million under a new term loan facility entered into in December 2020 that replaced the £60 million super senior revolving credit facility. There was additional amortization of capitalized bond issuance costs and other capitalized costs related to the refinancing in December 2020, partially offset by lower interest on finance leases following the surrender of a property lease in June 2020. We borrowed additional debt to fund liquidity during 2020 in response to the COVID-10 pandemic. Investor loan interest increased by £5.1 million, or 33.8%, from £15.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £20.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was due to the investment of £40 million from our shareholders in the Group, of which £10 million was received on August 24, 2020 and £30 million on December 2, 2020. _Finance Income_ Finance income remained relatively stable at £0.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to £0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our principal sources of liquidity have been cash generated from our operating activities and short and long-term borrowings. Following the Issue Date, we expect that our principal sources of liquidity will be our existing cash and cash equivalents, cash generated from operations, and our Senior Facilities. In connection with the Refinancing, on or about the Issue Date we intend to enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement, which provides for the £50.0 million Revolving Credit Facility and the £30.0 million Letter of Credit Facility. While the Revolving Credit Facility is not currently expected to be drawn as of the Issue Date, we will have issued letters of credit in an aggregate amount of £27.2 million under the Letter of Credit Facility as of the Issue Date. Our financial condition and liquidity have been, and are expected to continue to be, influenced by a variety of factors, including: - our ability to generate cash flows from our operations; - the level of our outstanding indebtedness, and the interest we are obligated to pay on such indebtedness, which affects our finance costs; - our ability to continue to borrow funds from banks; - our rent expenses; - our capital expenditure requirements; and - our level of acquisition and development activity. Our principal uses of funds are expected to consist mainly of funding capital expenditures and acquisitions or development activity, servicing indebtedness and financing working capital. As at the ----- date of this offering memorandum, after taking into account our current cash and cash equivalents and our anticipated cash flow from operating and financing activities, we believe that we have sufficient liquidity for our present requirements for at least the next twelve months. We may from time to time seek to retire or repurchase our outstanding debt through cash purchases, in open market purchases, privately negotiated transactions or otherwise. Such repurchases, if any, will depend on market conditions, our liquidity requirements, contractual restrictions and other factors. We had £154.2 million of cash and cash equivalents as of December 31, 2022.

Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Generated from / (used in) Operating Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash generated from operating activities increased by £202.6 million, from £277.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to £479.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Net cash generated from operating activities (before IFRS 16) increased by £154.7 million, or 194.8%, from £79.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £234.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase resulted primarily from a £156.9 million operating result improvement (after non-underlying items) and an increase of £0.4 million in the adjustment for depreciation, amortization and profit on disposal of fixed assets, partially offset by a £9.7 million of working capital outflow (predominantly due to the effect of the rent reductions agreed under the CVA on the “payable” resulting from spreading the CVA benefit over the life of lease, a decrease in prepaid room inflows following the reopening benefit in 2021 and an increase in rent prepayments following the rent reductions in 2021, partially offset by the increase in the VAT creditor) and a £0.4 million reduction in corporation tax repayments. Net cash generated from operating activities increased by £256.5 million, from £20.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £277.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Net cash generated from operating activities (before IFRS 16) was £79.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to £86.5 million of net cash used in operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was due to a £202.7 million operating result improvement (after non-underlying items) and an increase of £4.6 million in depreciation, amortization and impairment, partially offset by a decrease of £36.6 million in working capital inflow, (predominantly due to higher current year rent ----- prepayments and the “payable” resulting from spreading the CVA benefit over the life of lease, partially offset by higher inflows from prepaid rooms benefiting from the trading recovery), £4.6 million lower profit on disposal and a decrease of £0.4 million in corporation tax repayments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Used in Investing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash used in investing activities (before IFRS 16) increased by £38.6 million, or 112.5%, from £34.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £73.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase resulted primarily from a £40.4 million increase in capital expenditure in 2022, partially offset by £1.3 million of interest received due to higher cash balances, the increase in base rates and the partial repayment of a related-party loan and interest. Net cash used in investing activities (before IFRS 16) decreased by £1.3 million, or 34.4%, from £35.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to £34.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase resulted primarily from proceeds on the disposal of assets in 2020, partially offset by a reduction in capital expenditure in 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net Cash (Used in) / Generated From Financing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash used in financing activities increased by £155.9 million, from £236.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to £395.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Net cash used in financing activities (before IFRS 16) for the year ended December 31, 2022 increased by £111.3 million, or 289.8%, from net cash generated of £38.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 to £149.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Net cash used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2022 includes interest payments and finance fees of £42.7 million, the £40.0 million repayment of the our revolving credit facility in May 2022, the £61.9 million repayment of our term loan in October 2022, £3.3 million of finance costs related to the repayment of our term loan and finance lease interest payments of £1.8 million. Net cash generated from financing activities decreased from £49.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to net cash used in financing activities of £236.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Net cash used in financing activities (before IFRS 16) for the year ended December 31, 2021 was £38.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to net cash generated of £169.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Net cash used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2021 includes interest payments and finance fees of £35.8 million, finance lease interest payments of £1.2 million and costs associated with refinancing in December 2020 of £1.4 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditure of £74.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 primarily related to ongoing maintenance, health and safety works and IT, as well as spend on hotel refits, energy efficiency projects and development pipeline spending. Our capital expenditure of £34.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 primarily related to ongoing maintenance, health and safety and IT investments, as well as investments in energy efficiency projects, robotic vacuum cleaners and development of our pipeline. We deferred our ongoing hotel refurbishment program and reduced non-essential capital expenditure in 2021 in response to the impact of COVID-19. Our capital expenditure of £36.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 primarily related to ongoing maintenance and IT, as well as spend investments in energy efficiency projects committed prior to COVID-19, and development of our pipeline. We deferred our ongoing hotel refurbishment program and all non-essential capital expenditure in response to the impact of COVID-19 in 2020 and 2021. Our capital expenditure relating to development of the pipeline for the years ended December 2020, 2021 and 2022 was £1.0 million, £3.7 million and £4.3 million, respectively. Our growth capital ----- expenditures are limited since the hotels we operate are built by developers and we take a lease once they are complete. Our expenses during the development stage are limited to legal costs, fees of estate agents, planning consultants and project managers, loose fixtures and fittings and stamp duty land tax for the long-term leases of the newly developed hotels. At the time of practical completion of the newly developed hotels, we receive rebates from the developers to cover loose fixtures and fittings and legal costs. We intend to finance our capital expenditures mainly from the cash generated by our operating activities and cash on balance sheet. We currently budget our capital expenditures in 2023 to be approximately £90 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our trade and other receivables (before IFRS 16) primarily consist of rent prepayments, as we pay quarterly in advance. We have low trade receivables as most of our customers pay at the time of booking. However, business customers taking advantage of our business account card benefit from interest free credit. Inventories primarily includes food and beverage products sold through our bar café. Our liabilities to our trade and other creditors include prepaid room purchases from customers. Our current liabilities (before IFRS 16) include prepaid room purchases from customers who have yet to stay, as well as trade creditors, including rent, accrued wages and salaries, other current debts and accrued interest and taxes.
