Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have historically funded our working capital requirements through funds generated from our operations and from borrowings under our Revolving Credit Facility and other indebtedness. As is typical for a hotel business, we have a negative reported net working capital position, which fluctuates seasonally, primarily due to the timing of the payment of customer deposits and prepaid rents. Customers typically pay on booking or at check-in, resulting in low trade debtor days, while we typically pay our rent quarterly in advance around the end of March, June, September and December. Additionally, we generally pay vendors as well as staff once at the end of every calendar month in arrears, although weekly paid staff are on a 4-weekly payment cycle. As a result, our working capital position peaks at the end of March, June, September and December and is not indicative of our working capital requirements throughout the year. Our working capital inflow was £35.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to an outflow of £1.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Our working capital inflow (before IFRS 16 and before provisions and non-underlying items) was £25.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 compared to an inflow of £45.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due ----- to the effect of spreading the CVA benefit over the life of lease, partially offset by an increase in the VAT creditor and prepaid rooms benefits and the benefit from pre-paid rent movements. Our working capital outflow was £1.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to an outflow of £25.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our working capital cash inflow (before IFRS 16 and before provisions and non-underlying items) was £45.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to an inflow of £70.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to higher current year rent prepayments due to both the end of the reduced rents and the move back to quarterly from monthly payments for most hotels as the CVA ended, the repayment of VAT payments deferred in 2020 under the UK government’s COVID-19 support measures, the “payable” resulting from spreading the CVA benefit over the life of lease and higher business rates prepayments due to reduced hospitality business rates benefits. These were partially offset by higher inflows from prepaid rooms benefiting from the trading recovery, the receipt of furlough scheme claims, a lower December 2021 net VAT reclaim position (due to improved trading and rise in hospitality VAT rate) and the movement in trade payables and other trading related accruals due to improved trading levels.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We also have contingent liabilities under a number of leases that we assigned to various third parties. In certain circumstances, should the current lessee default on its obligations under the assigned lease agreement (including the payment of rent), the landlord may have recourse to us. Should the landlord make a claim against us for unpaid rent by the current lessee, we would be required to pay such outstanding rent, following which we could seize the unit subject to the claim, after petitioning the relevant court. As of December 31, 2022, the estimated annual contingent rental liability was £235.3 million, represented by 569 units with an average rental cost per unit of £0.4 million and an average lease term remaining of 13.9 years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We have adopted risk management procedures to both reduce and monitor credit risk. Our main financial assets include cash and cash equivalents, as well as trade and other accounts receivables. We have no significant concentration of third-party credit risk due to the diversification of our financial ----- investments, as well as to the distribution of trade risks with short collection periods among a large number of customers. Due to the nature of our operations, our trade receivables are relatively low and principally relate to monies owed from corporate accounts and travel agents, since individual customers typically pay in advance. We evaluate our bad debt provision on a regular basis for each debtor. We record a provision for any trade and other accounts receivable overdue more than 120 days. We recorded a provision for nonrecoverable bad debt in an amount of £0.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to £0.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Credit risk relating to cash and cash equivalents arises from the risk that the counterparty becomes insolvent and accordingly is unable to return the deposited funds as a result of the insolvency. To mitigate this risk, we seek to transact and deposit funds with financial institutions we deem credit worthy, and we monitor transaction volumes in order to reduce the risk of concentration of our transactions with any single party.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Following the offering of the Notes, we will have significant levels of floating rate borrowings, and thus we will be exposed to risks related to fluctuations in the levels of interest rates. We will not be required to hedge interest rate exposure under the Notes, but we may choose to do so in the future. We borrow at floating rates and we previously used an interest rate cap to limit the interest paid. The cap expired in October 2022. We continue to monitor our interest rate risk.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to exchange rate fluctuations. This exposure mainly arises from investment in foreign countries and transactions by entities operating in countries whose currency is not the pound sterling, such as Ireland and Spain. However, our exposure is limited due to the scale of these entities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk of not being able to fulfil present or future obligations if we do not have sufficient funds available to meet such obligations. Liquidity risk arises mostly in relation to cash flows generated and used in financing activities, and particularly by servicing our debt, in terms of both interest and capital, and our payment obligations relating to our ordinary business activities. We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity include: - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a lowering of income from our operations, which could be due to downturns in our performance or the industry as a whole; - adverse working capital developments; - exposure to increased interest rates in relation to our borrowings that bear interest at a variable rate; and - higher capital expenditures, including in connection with our brand repositioning initiative. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures; - reduce or delay our planned acquisitions; - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or ----- - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our activities expose us to a variety of financial risks, including credit risk, interest rate risk, foreign currency exchange risk, liquidity risk and market risks. Our risk management policy, which is managed centrally by our senior management, focuses on minimizing the potential adverse effects on our financial performance. The following section discusses the significant financial risks to which we are exposed. This discussion does not address other risks that we are exposed to in the normal course of business, such as operational risks. See “Risk Factors.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have assigned a fair market value to the Travelodge brand name, acquired through the acquisition of the Travelodge business. Impairment testing is performed annually by comparing the present value of the expected future cash flows from the business with the carrying amount of our net assets, including attributable intangible assets. The brand name acquired through the acquisition of the Travelodge Hotels Limited business was assigned a fair market value at the date of acquisition. The value of the brand name is reviewed annually for impairment. This is derived by estimating the amount of royalty income that could be generated from the brand name if it was owned by an independent third party using a royalty of 4% on forecast future revenues, which is considered to be the market value that could be achieved. The sales forecast is based on a sales forecast for the period 2023 - 27 and an estimated long term growth rate of 2%. The key assumptions are consistent with past experience and with external sources of information. This is discounted at the weighted average cost of capital for us of 8.9%, which is calculated using the Capital Asset Pricing Model and referencing inputs from a portfolio of similar hotel businesses. We consider the value of the brand name, which was first introduced into the UK in 1985, will be maintained almost indefinitely and is therefore not amortized. The model can be sensitized to reduce the royalty rate to 0.9% or the discount factor rate would need to increase to 30.4% before an impairment is triggered.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Significant judgment is involved in the process of determining the appropriate lease terms to apply upon inception or when lease modifications are calculated. We consider it reasonably certain that landlords will exercise the options granted to them under our CVA agreement to extend leases, e.g., for a further three, five or seven years. For affected leases, the extension period has been added to the noncancellable period of the lease term in calculating the lease liability and right of use asset. For leases where we, as tenant, have the option to renew for a further 25 or 35 years upon expiration of the lease, we do not believe such a determination can be made at this time with reasonable certainty, and for such leases this extension period has not been added to the non-cancellable period of the lease term in calculating the lease liability and right of use asset.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We use estimation in determining the appropriate discount rates to apply when new leases are entered into and lease modifications are calculated. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires that management apply accounting standards and methods which, under certain circumstances, are based upon difficult subjective measurements and estimates based upon past experience and on assumptions considered, at various times, to be reasonable and realistic in terms of the respective circumstances. The use of such estimates and assumptions affects the amounts reported in the Financial Statements as well as the information disclosed. Actual results for those areas requiring management judgment or estimates may differ from those recorded in the financial statements due to the occurrence of events and the uncertainties which characterize the assumptions and conditions on which the estimates are based. The primary areas applicable to us that require greater subjectivity of management in making estimates and where a change in the conditions underlying the assumptions could have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements include:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The UK lodging sector is a large and growing sector comprised of numerous modes of accommodation including hotels, private rentals, campsites, self-catering apartments and hostels. According to Euromonitor International Limited’s (“Euromonitor”) report “Lodging (Destination) in the United Kingdom” dated October 2022, hotels are by far the largest segment, representing approximately 71% of sector sales in 2022, down from 76% in 2019. With regard to the distribution channel split, online and offline sales stood at 76% and 24% in 2022 compared to 68% and 32% in 2019, respectively. UK lodging sales can be broken down by type of accommodation and distribution channel as follows: _Source: Euromonitor’s report “Lodging (Destination) in the United Kingdom” dated October 2022. _ Note: Other Lodging included as per Euromonitor definition; Campsites, Hostels and Other Lodging Types.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The UK hotel industry has significantly rebounded back in revenue terms following COVID-19, and generated approximately £19.3 billion in 2022, compared to £17.3 billion in 2019 (£6.7 billion in London and £10.6 billion in the regions), with 16,392 hotels and 679,215 hotel rooms in 2022 according to STR. For STR data relating to the UK industry as a whole, figures for London and the regions have been summed together. As of December 2022, UK hotel room revenues have increased at a CAGR of 4.4% over the last ten years as compared to 1.6% for real UK GDP (Source: International Monetary Fund (“IMF”)). Hotel market performance is generally measured by three metrics: (1) Average room rate (“ARR”); (2) occupancy; and (3) revenue per available room (“RevPAR”). ARR represents hotel room revenue divided by total number of rooms sold in a given period, measuring average room price attained by a hotel. Occupancy represents the total number of rooms sold divided by the total number of rooms available at a hotel or group of hotels, measuring the utilization of hotels’ available capacity. RevPAR is calculated by dividing hotel room revenue by Room Nights available to guests for the period. Because RevPAR combines two key drivers of operations at hotels, ARR and occupancy, it is commonly used to measure performance over comparable periods. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: UK Hotel Industry Represents a Large Captive Market Characterized by 68 million Resident Population and a Significant Number of Hotels, Rooms and Demand Nights
Subsubsection Text: Hotel companies conduct business using four main models which are characterized by ownership of the underlying assets, operating leverage and maintenance requirements, among others: - _Owned: The hotel asset is fully owned and operated by the hotel brand. The owner/operator has full responsibility for all expenses and costs; - _Leased: The hotel asset is leased by a hotel brand on a long-term contract. The hotel brand pays rent for the “walls,” operates all aspects of the business and is responsible for all major expenses and costs. In this model, the underlying property is typically owned by institutional investors such as pension funds or by wealthy individuals. We operate the majority of our business using the leased model; - _Franchised: The hotel asset is owned and/or operated by a third-party and the hotel brand acts as a franchisor, granting a license to distribute goods or services using their trademarks, trade names, trade styles and business systems. The hotel brand (franchisor) typically earns fees on a room revenue basis and provides assistance with site selection, personnel training, business set-up, advertising, and product supply; and - _Managed: The hotel asset is typically owned by a third party and managed by the hotel brand which collects fees based on top and bottom line performance of the hotel. In a management agreement, the hotel brand basically provides the same services as a franchise agreement, such as brand and reservation system, but also operates the hotel. In this model the owner is ultimately responsible for the costs and expenses related to operating the hotel.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: According to Research Company STR terminology, the hotel market is classified into three broad categories: - _Luxury and Upper Upscale: Luxury and Upper Upscale hotels offer the highest room rates and typically offer a broader range of products and services to customers, including meeting room facilities, multiple dining options and spa/wellness facilities. The clientele for Luxury and Upper Upscale hotels is mixed, including both business travelers and more affluent leisure guests. Certain of these hotels may be located in seaside or other vacation destinations and may be tailored to vacation and leisure travelers. Key market participants in the Luxury and Upper Upscale segment are Four Seasons, Hilton and Marriott; - _Upscale and Upper Midscale: Upscale and Upper Midscale hotels typically offer room rates that are in the middle of the price spectrum and provide food and beverage services beyond breakfast but typically do not offer the full spectrum of services that Luxury and Upper Upscale hotels offer. Key market participants in the Upscale and Upper Midscale segment are Holiday Inn, Novotel and Britannia Hotels; and - _Midscale and Economy (“MS&E”): The MS&E segment typically offers the lowest rates per room and usually offer limited additional services, or offer services such as food and beverage at an additional cost. In 2022, the segment generated £4.9 billion of revenue from 247,062 rooms, which accounted for 36% of the total number of rooms in the UK, according to STR. The total number of demand nights in the MS&E segment was 71.1 million in 2022, according to the same source, with occupancy and ARR of 79.0% and £69.89 respectively. This translated into RevPAR of £55.41, up by 18.4% vs 2019. Occupancy, ARR and RevPAR figures for the MS&E segment have been calculated on a weighted average basis of London and the regions, weighted by revenue. Key market participants in the UK MS&E segment are the branded budget hotels Travelodge and Premier Inn, which together comprise the majority of the segment according to management estimates. The MS&E segment has proven to be highly resilient throughout economic cycles: - The MS&E segment has significantly recovered from COVID-19, with revenues increasing 19.5% from 2019 to 2022, driven by greater pricing power and higher occupancy numbers as a result of the easing of COVID-19 restrictions. ARR and occupancy figures are also higher than 2019 by 16.9% and 1.5%, respectively; - In times of economic downturn, cost conscious businesses and leisure customers trade down and MS&E hotels are able to outperform the market average, which is particularly relevant in the current inflationary environment; and ----- - The segment has also shown resilience to previous economic cycles. According to STR, during the financial crisis of 2008, RevPAR fell at a CAGR of 3.2% between 2007 and 2009 vs 4.8% for the overall UK market. For the period between 2019 and 2022, London RevPAR CAGR was 3.9% for the MS&E segment vs 2.1% for general hospitality, and UK regional RevPAR was 6.9% for the MS&E segment vs 4.6% for general hospitality.

We also maintain applicable compulsory workers’ compensation and motor liability coverage. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: The MS&E Segment Is Outperforming in the UK
Subsubsection Text: Historically, the performance of the UK hotel industry has been closely correlated to the strength of the UK economy generally, and of the local economies where hotels are situated. There was a close correlation between RevPAR and GDP, especially in the regional UK hospitality market, until the COVID-19 pandemic began, which disrupted hotel operations and impacted the relationship between GDP and RevPAR. However, while it remains unclear where we stand in the current cycle, we believe that the relationship between RevPAR and GDP is likely to normalize in the future. This is in line with what happened following the 2008-2009 financial crisis where, as illustrated in the graph below titled “Long-term relationship between change in real GDP growth and UK hotel RevPar,” RevPAR and GDP growth partially decoupled (particularly in 2009), to then recover their correlation in following years. While Real GDP growth for the UK in 2023 is predicted to be 0.3% compared to 3.6% for 2022 according to the IMF, London RevPAR is forecasted to increase by 12.9% in 2023 according to STR. Such growth can be attributed to both an increase of occupancy (from 74.7% to 80.9%), and an increase in ARR (from £183.1 to £190.8), accordingly to STR data, reflecting a recovery in occupied rooms, as well as the ability of hotels to pass inflation through to their clients, to a certain extent. Regional RevPAR growth is expected to be 9.3% in 2023, which is also substantially higher than GDP growth for the UK, highlighting the present lack of correlation between the pair. At the same time, the MS&E segment is also expected to perform strongly in 2023, with London and Regional RevPAR forecasted to increase respectively by 7.2% and 3.9%. Such growth rates for the MS&E segment are partially lower vs. total market, but remain higher than expected Real GDP growth and reflect the faster 2022 recovery of the MS&E segment compared to the total market and London faster than the regions due to the slower 2022 London recovery compared to the regions. More generally, hotel market performance over the past 22 years falls broadly into four phases, in parallel with UK GDP: (I) strong growth between 2000 and 2007; (ii) a recessionary period between 2007 and 2009; (iii) an initially slow recovery in 2010 to 2012, followed by a more rapid period of growth thereafter; and (iv) the COVID-19-induced pandemic and subsequent lockdowns, followed by a sharp recovery post-COVID-19. The chart below outlines the long-term relationship between the change in real GDP growth and UK hotel RevPAR: -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Long-term relationship between change in real GDP growth and UK hotel RevPar
Subsubsection Text: Source: PwC Research November 2022 (UK Hotels Forecast 2022-2023). As can be seen from the graph above, COVID-19 had a significant impact on the hotel market and overall economy, which resulted in a mechanical drop in RevPAR in 2020 and affected most sectors of the economy: - Several strict lockdowns, especially in 2020, prevented leisure or business hotel bookings to take place as restrictions made any type of travel impossible; - Increased caution amongst the population preventing people from traveling, even when there were no lockdowns imposed; and - Repeated variants and waves forced governments to impose restrictions on international travel, reducing the amount of inbound and outbound travelers. Starting in 2021, the broader economy started to reopen. The breakout of the COVID-19 variant Omicron was contained by the successful rollout of the vaccine booster program, and the dissipation of COVID-19 and related restrictions combined with the return of regular international travel were, according to Euromonitor, the driving forces behind the recovery of the lodging market in 2022. The hotel sector was well positioned to capture the post-COVID-19 rebound, benefiting from consumers’ pent-up demand for experiences and travel once the domestic economy re-opened. Forbes also explains that an increasing number of consumers would rather spend on experiences and explore more rather than material items following COVID-19 lockdowns. Moreover, for UK residents looking to travel abroad, administrative procedures related to COVID-19 and the Omicron variant, such as the need to test prior to travel, increased the popularity of “staycations” and indirectly benefited the UK lodging market. Euromonitor highlights that the increase in ARRs for self-contained accommodation due to higher demand will likely prove advantageous for hostels, budget and mid-market hotels, which represents a potential positive development for our Company. ----- The increased geopolitical and economic uncertainty observed over recent years has also resulted in increased pressure on consumer income and has dampened consumer confidence. This will affect priorities of consumers, who are more likely to stay price-conscious, creating a trade down opportunity for the MS&E segment. Similar trends have been observed in other leisure sectors (hotels, gyms, etc.) as the negative general sentiment amongst the public leads to customers trading down. Indeed, our Company’s revenues for the first 12 weeks of 2023 have been approximately 30% and 40% ahead of 2022 and 2019 levels, respectively, highlighting its resilience as well as that of the sector. Source: Company Information.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: London hotel RevPAR grew materially between 2009 and 2022 at a CAGR of 3.1%. PwC Research expects that international travel to London will continue to improve, reaching 87% of pre-COVID levels at year-end 2023, which will support the recovery. The UK capital remains a key location for tourism, hosting 6 out of 20 Premier League clubs and a wealth of events and historical attractions, paired with its continued relevance for business travelers as evidenced by the ranking as 2nd global financial center in the 31st Global Financial Centre’s Index. London has bounced back strongly, as evidenced by: - 18.9% growth in ARR in 2022 compared to 2019, and occupancy at (8.7)% below 2019 levels in 2022, leading to an increase of 6.6% in RevPAR over the same timeframe; - Strong YoY recovery continued through 2022; at year end ARR, occupancy and RevPAR had grown by 50.5%, 37.1% and 199.1% vs. 2021, respectively, according to STR; - Continued growth forecasted in 2023; at year end ARR, occupancy and RevPAR to grow by 4.2%, 6.2% and 12.9% vs. 2022, respectively, according to STR; and - Forecasted growth into 2024, with levels of ARR at 24.3%, occupancy at 0.7% and RevPAR at 25.3% above 2019. The recent revenue growth was mostly driven by rate increases, while further expansion will also be driven by an increase in occupancy. To conclude, we believe the strong growth in ARR and sustained increase in visitors will continue in the future. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: RevPAR recovered strongly between 2009 and 2022, growing at a CAGR of 3.6%. The Regional market is further expected to bounce back once the UK economy recovers, potentially catching up with London in terms of growth. PwC Research also notes that cities such as Edinburgh which are popular with tourists will also profit from a weak sterling, and events such as the 2023 Eurovision Song Contest and the UCI Cycling World Championships will benefit cities such as Liverpool and Glasgow, where increases in room supply are forecasted to be the largest in the UK. Our regional revenues for Q1 2023 are ahead of 2022 levels, with strong leisure and blue collar demand. According to STR, this recovery did not lose momentum over the course of the year, and at year end both ARR and RevPAR had grown by 8.6% and 59.4%, respectively. Both will continue growing into 2024: - 17.3% growth in ARR in 2022 compared to 2019, and occupancy (2.0)% lower than 2019 levels in 2022, leading to an increase of 14.3% in RevPAR over the same period; - Sustained YoY recovery continued through 2022; at year end ARR, occupancy and RevPAR were 8.6%, 23.4% and 59.4% up on 2021 figures, respectively, according to STR; - Continued growth forecasted in 2023; at year end ARR, occupancy and RevPAR to grow by 4.1%, 3.7% and 9.3% vs. 2022, respectively, according to STR; and - Forecasted growth into 2024, with levels of ARR 23.3%, occupancy at 1.5% and RevPAR at 25.8% growth above 2019. -----

Subsubsection Text: Industry experts consider macro-economic factors, travel and tourism activity and population growth to be among the key demand drivers for hotels.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Real GDP continued to rally in 2022 following a strong recovery in 2021, highlighting the resilience of the UK economy. While growth has naturally slowed and is currently mild, it is expected to gain momentum in the coming years, with 2.3% real GDP growth projected for 2025. This economic upturn is expected to complement low levels of unemployment, and this will drive increased economic prosperity in the coming years as the UK begins to successfully navigate the post-Brexit and postCOVID-19 landscape.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: HM Treasury’s March 2023 report. Travel and Tourism
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the UK is likely to continue to remain an attractive destination for international tourist arrivals, driven by international business travelers, vacationers and international travelers visiting friends and relatives. ----- According to the ONS, the number of overseas visitors to the UK increased at a ten year CAGR of 2.8% from 2009 to 2019. COVID-19 caused numbers to drop; preliminary results indicate however that the number of overseas visitors to the UK in 2022 was nearly 75% of the 2019 figure of 40.9 million visits, indicating a positive trend and suggesting a potential return to normality in coming years. PwC Research also notes that current inflationary pressures will have differing impacts in London compared to regional UK. The London hotel landscape is more shaped by the state of international travel and exchange rates, whereas the health of UK regional hotels is more tied to that of the UK economy in general. A consumer sentiment survey conducted by PwC in September 2022 showed that an increasing number of UK consumers expected to stay in less expensive accommodations, a development which could be positive for Travelodge. However, London has seen and will to continue to experience demand from international tourists, supported by major events throughout 2023 such as England’s Six Nations rugby matches and the coronation of King Charles III. This will support future travel to London, and international visitors are expected to outnumber domestic visitors to the capital from 2023 onwards, according to STR. Business demand is also experiencing positive trends, recovering from COVID-19 and seeing increased business travel. The market is currently experiencing strong “blue collar” demand with a continued recovery of “white collar” demand over the last months, and Travelodge itself is experiencing continued growth in business customers, with positive demand drivers (such as change in working patterns) continuing to underpin potential growth in business demand. At the same time, as previously noted, we expect leisure travel to continue to enjoy several positive demand drivers such as consumers continuing to prioritize experiences over material purchases, strong events pipeline supporting demand and sustained “staycation” demand.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: According to ONS, the UK population is projected to increase by 2.1 million over ten years from an estimated 67.1 million in mid-2020 to 69.2 million in mid-2030, with England growing faster than other UK nations. The population growth is expected to be driven by a net 2.2 million people immigrating into the UK during this same period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The new hotel developments have resumed post COVID-19. The increase in supply in London is the largest since the lead up to the London 2012 Olympics, according to PwC Research. ----- - _London: 10,505 rooms, equating to 91 properties, were under construction as of February 2023, with 12,377 (154 properties) more in final planning stages, according to STR. 9,507 rooms (73 properties) are due to open between 2023-2025 as of February 2023, representing a 6.4% increase on existing stock as of December 31, 2022; and - _Regions: 28,426 rooms (328 properties) were under construction as of February 2023, according to STR, with a further 51,617 (997 properties) in final planning stages. 24,978 rooms (221 properties) are forecasted to open between 2023-2025, as of February 2023, a 4.6% on existing stock in December 2022. 628 rooms (four properties) are also scheduled to open in 2026, as of February 2023. Cities with the largest number of rooms under construction include Manchester, Glasgow, Birmingham and Edinburgh, according to PwC. STR believes that over the long run, demand will outstrip supply for the general hotel sector. Furthermore, according to STR, the penetration of the midscale and economy segment as a percentage of total hotel rooms in which we operate is lower in the UK (at approximately 37%) as compared to France (at approximately 60%), providing the opportunity for branded hotel businesses like Travelodge to grow.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Midscale & Economy Segment Penetration as Percentage of Total Hotel Rooms
Subsubsection Text: In the UK, local hotel operators generally compete with a variety of local and international hotel operators. Some international hotel operators operate under well-known international brand names, while others have established a long-standing presence in certain regions or cities. In mid-size urban areas and suburbs of large cities, branded hotel operators primarily compete with local and international chains, as well as independently owned and managed hotels. Depending upon the class of the hotel, competition is focused primarily upon price, including discounted and promotional pricing, quality of facilities and services offered, physical location within a particular market and the ability to earn and redeem customer loyalty program points. Hotel owners and operators are required to modernize, refurbish and maintain their hotels on a regular basis in order to compete effectively with other hotels. Today, significant participants are Premier Inn, Travelodge, IHG, Hilton, Marriott and Accor. -----

We believe this confers significant advantages on Travelodge, including brand recognition and above-average direct sales distribution via our own websites and call center. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 90% of our bookings were made through direct bookings, including approximately 80% made through our websites and approximately 10% through walk-ins, call centers and Groups. Our main competitors for hotel stays are other midscale and value international and local chains. We primarily compete with Premier Inn, the largest hotel operator in the UK based on number of rooms and number of hotels. We also compete with other value brands such as Holiday Inn Express, Ibis Hotel, and Comfort Inn. We compete with other hotel brands, travel agents and online distributors such as booking.com for hotel bookings, as well as other shared economy providers, for example Airbnb, and meta-search providers such as Kayak or Trivago. Travelodge has consistently outperformed competitors, with stronger YoY performances compared to the MS&E segment as a whole since 2015, regardless of the macroeconomic backdrop. Our postCOVID-19 recovery has been significantly stronger than that the segment, with 2021 and 2022 figures up by 1,080 and 1,090 bps, respectively. This is reflected in our consistently high customer scores, which will help fuel future growth and ensure that our hotels continue to stand out within the MS&E segment. -----
