Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Founded in 1985, Travelodge is the second largest hotel brand in the United Kingdom based on number of hotels and number of rooms operated. We leased, franchised, managed and owned 595 hotels and approximately 46,000 rooms throughout the United Kingdom, Spain and Ireland as of December 31, 2022. We operate in the midscale and economy (“MS&E”) segment of the hotel market (as defined by STR) and are positioned as a budget operator, offering standardized, modern guest rooms at affordable prices to both business and leisure customers. Our purpose is to provide affordable travel for everyone and we aim to offer our customers the right balance of location, price and quality for their travel needs. As of December 31, 2022, we had brand recognition of 98% among the UK population (as measured by a YouGov brand tracking survey), driven by our long-standing market presence, wide geographic network and effective marketing initiatives. We operate multiple room formats across our hotels, namely our core standard rooms (43,442 in 595 hotels as of December 31, 2022), which include twin, family and accessible rooms, and our “premium economy” SuperRooms (2,319 in 64 hotels across the United Kingdom and Ireland as of December 31, 2022). We estimate that we attracted approximately 21 million customers in 2022, well exceeding our previous pre-COVID-19 pandemic peak of approximately 19 million customers in 2019. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 90% of our bookings were made through direct bookings, including approximately 80% made through our websites and approximately 10% through walk-ins, call centers and Groups. We operate a lean, low-cost operating model, with a relatively small support office and a high proportion of hourly paid team members in hotels. We employ approximately 12,000 people across our hotels and support offices, the majority of whom work in our hotels on hourly paid contracts. As of December 31, 2022, we operated 45,761 rooms in 595 hotels under the Travelodge brand. Within our largest market, the United Kingdom (excluding Northern Ireland), representing 98% of our total revenue in the year ended December 31, 2022, we operated 43,914 rooms (or 96% of total rooms) in 579 hotels, with 9,888 rooms (or 23% of UK rooms) in 79 hotels located in London and 34,026 rooms (or 77% of UK rooms) in 500 hotels located in regional areas across the United Kingdom. The majority of our hotels in the United Kingdom are leasehold. We also operate one hotel under a freehold and 10 hotels under management contracts in the United Kingdom. As of December 31, 2022, 1,226 rooms in 11 hotels were operated under franchise in Ireland and Northern Ireland, including a new central Dublin City Center hotel opened in 2022, and we operated 621 rooms in five hotels under leasehold in Spain. In early 2023, we opened our first new Spanish hotel in over ten years in Madrid. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated revenue, EBITDA (adjusted) and RevPAR of £909.9 million, £212.9 million and £52.59, respectively, compared to £727.9 million, £129.1 million and £42.46 for the year ended December 31, 2019. Between the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2022, our revenue, EBITDA (adjusted) and RevPAR grew at a CAGR of 7.7%, 18.2% and 7.4%, respectively. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we had Occupancy and an Average Room Rate of 81.8% and £64.31, respectively, compared to 80.8% and £52.51 for the year ended December 31, 2019. ----- 93% of our UK revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022 was generated from accommodation, with the remainder from food and beverage and retail and other sales, including Wi-Fi, car parking and other guest services. The following map indicates the number of rooms that we operated by region as of December 31, 2022: The United Kingdom has one of the largest and most resilient hotel markets in the world, with the segment having already significantly recovered from COVID-19, and RevPAR growing at a CAGR of 4.4% over the last ten years (according to STR data, compared to 1.6% for real UK GDP (Source: International Monetary Fund (“IMF”)). Historically, the performance of the UK hotel industry has been closely correlated to the strength of the UK economy and of the local regions where hotels are situated. Even though the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted hotel operations and impacted the relationship between GDP and RevPAR, we believe that this will normalize in the future. Starting in 2021, the broader economy started to reopen and the breakout of the COVID-19 variant Omicron was contained by the successful rollout of the vaccine booster program. The dissipation of COVID-19 and related restrictions combined with the return of regular international travel were, according to Euromonitor, the driving forces behind the recovery of the lodging market in 2022. The hotel sector was well positioned to capture the post-COVID-19 rebound, benefiting from consumers’ pent-up demand for experiences and travel once the domestic economy re-opened. In particular, the MS&E segment has proven to be highly resilient throughout economic cycles, achieving a significant recovery from COVID-19, with revenues increasing 19.5% from 2019 to 2022. The MS&E segment is outperforming in the UK, with RevPAR growth above the total hospitality sector. Moreover, a recent consumer sentiment survey conducted by PwC in September 2022 showed that an increasing number of UK consumers expected to stay in less expensive accommodations, a development which could be positive for the MS&E segment. As such, we believe there are opportunities to grow the MS&E segment’s share of the UK market and, with a promising secured pipeline, we expect to maintain a regular program of new room openings. The UK hotel market remains relatively fragmented with a variety of local and international hotel operators and independents. We believe the fragmentation of the market presents opportunities for us to grow due to our strong brand recognition and scale. We benefit from high levels of customer satisfaction which we attribute to the quality of our offering and standardized work practices. We have made significant investments to strengthen the quality of our offering. We launched our “premium economy” room type, SuperRooms, which offers an enhanced specification, including a coffee machine, rain shower, choice of pillow and in-room hairdryer, iron and ironing board. In early 2022, we launched a new design, which includes a series of non-capital intensive ----- enhancements to transform the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés based on market feedback from extensive customer research. The new design seeks to drive higher demand and rate premiums by delivering a warmer and more welcoming environment with updated room features, including blackout curtains, USB charging points by the bed, a comfortable armchair and an upgraded bathroom. Our new design also delivers a new style bar café in our bar café hotels, offering a more flexible environment in which to eat, relax or work. In 2022, we upgraded 64 hotels and over 6,000 rooms (approximately 14% of the room estate) with our new design, with positive commercial and customer feedback, and we plan to upgrade over 4,000 rooms (approximately 10% of the room estate) in 2023. We plan to refurbish our entire estate over an approximately seven-year refit cycle. The investments in our estate are supported by a standardized and disciplined approach to operations, a lean operating model and efficient cost control, all of which drive profitability. We operate our hotels with a standardized room cleaning process, we have processes in place to monitor our customers’ experience, we provide in-person and online training modules for our employees and we rigorously benchmark our performance by using internal customer surveys and external benchmarking, such as TripAdvisor surveys. In addition, we continue to optimize our operating model by introducing technology to simplify, standardize and automate, including our investments in robot vacuums across our estate, which has helped to reduce the physical demands of the job for our employees, reduce our energy consumption and deliver cost efficiencies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Compelling long-term growth fundamentals in the resilient and underpenetrated budget hospitality market
Subsubsection Text: The United Kingdom has one of the world’s largest and most resilient hotel markets in the world with attractive characteristics. The UK hotel industry generated approximately £20 billion in room revenue in 2022, with approximately 16,392 hotels and 679,215 hotel rooms, according to STR data. Hotel travel by domestic guests has historically benefitted from strong business investment, employment levels, wages, consumer spending and consumer confidence in the UK. The UK hotel industry also benefits from a large number of travelers coming to the United Kingdom from other countries, for business travel and tourism, including for large events. Historically, the performance of the UK hotel industry has correlated with the strength of the UK economy generally, being closely related to GDP. Although the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted operations and impacted the relationship between GDP and RevPAR, we believe that this will normalize in the future. Nevertheless, the UK Hotel industry has been able to achieve substantial growth rates: as of December 2022, UK hotel room revenues have increased at a CAGR of 4.4% over the last ten years as compared to 1.6% for real UK GDP. The chart below shows the long-term relationship between the change in real GDP growth and UK hotel RevPAR: ----- _ Source: PwC Research November 2022 (UK Hotels Forecast 2022-2023)._ We are one of the two largest hotel brands in the UK MS&E segment, as defined by STR. Such segment has proven to be highly resilient throughout economic cycles, as in times of economic downturn, cost conscious businesses and leisure customers typically trade down and MS&E hotels are able to outperform the market average, which is particularly relevant in the current inflationary environment. RevPAR for the MS&E segment has recovered strongly from the COVID-19 pandemic. RevPAR for the MS&E segment in 2022 was 18% above RevPAR for the UK hotel market, which had only reached 2019 levels. Our UK like-for-like RevPAR for the year ended December 31, 2022 was approximately 10.9% ahead of the MS&E segment partly due to strong leisure demand and a rapid recovery in “blue collar” demand, with a more gradual recovery in “white collar” demand. While the current macro-economic environment creates uncertainty, the budget hotel segment has proven resilient, performing well during challenging economic periods relative to other segments and we expect the segment to benefit from a number of positive demand drivers, including continued staycation demand, consumers trading down to budget hotels, changes in working patterns, events and indirectly from inbound tourism as a result of the weak Pound. We believe that the MS&E segment is more resilient during times of economic hardship than other segments, in part, because cost conscious business and leisure customers trade down during those periods. Our revenue and RevPAR increased at a CAGR of 7.7% and 7.4%, respectively, between the year ended December 31, 2019 and the year ended December 31, 2022, while our EBITDA (adjusted) increased from £129.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to £212.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Alongside like-for-like RevPAR growth potential, we also believe there is further opportunity to increase the penetration of branded budget hotels in the United Kingdom. The MS&E segment of the UK hotel market accounted for approximately 37% of total hotel rooms compared to 60% in France (based on data produced by STR). As a result, we believe there are significant opportunities to grow the budget sector and the share of branded budget rooms in the United Kingdom.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Leading market position driven by outstanding brand recognition and well invested network of hotels with proven and sustained market outperformance throughout economic cycles
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong position in the UK hotel market. We were the first budget hotel brand to launch in the United Kingdom and we had brand recognition of more than 98% among the UK population as of December 31, 2022, as measured by a YouGov brand tracking survey. Our modern hotels and standardized operational processes have allowed us to deliver high levels of customer satisfaction. As ----- of December 31, 2022, our UK hotels had an average TripAdvisor score of four dots out of five, we received 287 TripAdvisor Traveler’s Choice Awards and 89% of our UK hotels were rated four dots or higher on Trip Advisor (from 88% in 2020 and growing or remaining stable every year since). This combination of customer satisfaction and operational discipline, has helped our UK like-for-like RevPAR growth to outperform the MS&E segment since 2015. We also have significant scale in the United Kingdom. We are the second largest hotel brand in the United Kingdom based on number of hotels and number of rooms operated, with 595 hotels and 45,761 rooms as of December 31, 2022 (of which 579 hotels and 43,914 rooms specifically in the UK). Our network is highly diversified with a strong presence throughout the UK, including a large footprint in London (9,888 rooms (or 23% of UK rooms) in 79 hotels as of December 31, 2022) and the rest of our hotels spread throughout other regional areas in the United Kingdom (34,026 rooms (or 77% of UK rooms) in 500 hotels as of December 31, 2022).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Compelling guest proposition with attractive customer profile and advantageous business leisure mix
Subsubsection Text: We have a well invested estate, including six (including London Docklands Central, which replaced an existing hotel, and the Irish franchise in Dublin City Center) that have been newly opened since the beginning of 2022. Our rooms are designed with simplicity and cleanliness in mind, with upgraded facilities contributing to a positive customer experience. In early 2022, we launched a new design, which includes a series of non-capital intensive enhancements to transform the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés based on market feedback from extensive customer research. The new design seeks to drive higher demand and rate premiums by delivering a warmer and more welcoming environment with updated room features, including blackout curtains, USB charging points by the bed, a comfortable armchair and an upgraded bathroom, and a new style format bar café in our bar café hotels, offering a more flexible environment in which to eat, relax or work. In 2022, we upgraded 64 hotels and over 6,000 rooms (approximately 14% of the room estate) with our new design, with positive commercial and customer feedback, and we plan to upgrade over 4,000 rooms (approximately 10% of the room estate) in 2023. We plan to refurbish our entire estate over an expected seven year cycle, with interim works in selected hotels with heavier usage patterns. We have a multi-faceted customer base. For the year ended December 31, 2022, demand and customers spread across many unrelated sectors such as leisure, blue collar and white collar, and we estimate that approximately half our customers were business guests and half were leisure guests, with blue collar customers and white collar customers accounting for approximately 30% and 20%, respectively, of our UK customer base. We have offered business memberships to our business customers since 2016. In 2022, we had over 36,000 business membership sign-ups representing a 9% increase compared to 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Highly effective revenue management system with best in class direct distribution model and customer acquisition
Subsubsection Text: We use our direct distribution platform to sell rooms directly to our customers without an intermediary. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 90% of our bookings were made through direct bookings, including approximately 80% made through our websites and approximately 10% through walk-ins, call centers and Groups. Our leading direct distribution platform consistently delivers approximately 80% Occupancy across our hotels. We believe that large numbers of customers book directly with us due to our large-scale brand recognition, presence and simple, user-friendly website that is optimized for mobile use. We believe that our predominantly direct distribution platform gives us greater access to our customers and more control over the booking process, while reducing our overall direct marketing and commission costs. Our pricing is centrally managed by a dedicated team, which uses an optimized revenue management system. We completed a major revenue management system upgrade in 2019, which in conjunction with investments in our data and analytics capability, has enhanced our strong performance after the COVID-19 pandemic. Our revenue management system uses all available information to forecast demand for each hotel and to optimize prices. Our rates are updated three times per day as internal and ----- external factors change. We have a dedicated events team to monitor key events, such as large attendance concerts, sports events and cultural events, to set and adjust event specific pricing based on forecast demand. Our centralized team uses high-quality reporting, benchmarking and data analytics to monitor performance and adjust pricing in real time to further optimize the prices charged.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Lean operating model, including significant proportion of CPI capped rent reviews, driving profitability and cash flows. Strong development pipeline with low upfront capex needs
Subsubsection Text: We operate a lean, low-cost operating model, with a relatively small support office and a high proportion of hourly paid team members in hotels. In the United Kingdom, excluding rent, depreciation and amortization, 36% of our operating costs were spent on hotel wages, 18% were spent on other property expenses, 10% were spent on cost of goods sold, including laundry and food and beverages, 10% on our central headquarters, 5% on marketing, 5% on maintenance, 3% on commission and 13% other costs) in the year ended December 31, 2022. We have implemented a range of measures to maintain the quality of our offering and reduce our costs. These measures include using predictive models to forecast occupancy at our hotels and align our employee rotas accordingly, optimizing internal processes to reduce the time it takes to complete certain tasks, training our housekeeping teams in multiple skill-sets to increase productivity and reduce personnel costs, and using a dedicated internal maintenance team to carry out routine maintenance. In addition, we have implemented new policies and technology to lower personnel costs, such as shorter hours with dedicated reception support. We also introduced robot vacuums across the estate, helping to reduce the physical demands of the job for our team members, reducing our energy consumption and delivering cost efficiencies. We have also continued to invest in automation of tasks with our Perfect Stay mobile application and energy efficiency measures in our hotels. In 2021, we brought a significant proportion of the remaining outsourced maintenance activity in-house, driving increased efficiency. We continue to selectively use outsourced services where greater service levels or opportunities to reduce costs are available, including certain complex maintenance work, certain aspects of information technology management and telephone bookings and support. As of December 31, 2022, we operated 568, or 95%, of our hotels under leases and we owned one of our hotels. The rest of our hotels are operated under management or franchise agreements. We lease almost all of our hotels through long-term arrangements with landlords, which allows us to expand our portfolio with low upfront capital expenditure, as the vast majority of the upfront construction costs of each hotel are funded by the freehold owner or developer. Development costs, which are incurred by our landlords, vary according to location and building configuration, but typically range between £80,000 and £90,000 per room excluding land (excluding certain locations such as London, where such costs are higher). New leases are normally 25 years, although properties in city centers and London are occasionally operated on terms of 35 years or longer. Most of our leases are subject to standard fiveyearly upwards-only rent reviews (some of which have upper and lower limits (“caps and collars”) on the amount the rent can increase at each review date), and are indexed against RPI or CPI, which allows for relative predictability of rental expenses. In January 2023, we completed a lease re-gear for 97 of our hotels (the “LXI Re-gear”). As part of the LXI Re-gear, rent reviews moved to a CPI + 0.5% per annum basis with caps and collars (4% per annum and 1% per annum, respectively) replacing the previously uncapped and uncollared RPI rent reviews. We expect to re-gear leases for an additional 25 hotels, subject to obtaining superior landlord consent, in the second quarter of 2023. As of December 31, 2022, we had entered into agreements to lease more than 22 new hotels with more than 2,100 rooms (our “secured pipeline”) and we expect to open eight hotels and approximately 600 rooms in 2023. In the next few years, we plan to return to our normal hotel opening rate of 15 to 20 each year as market conditions improve. The overall UK rent cover for leases has increased from 0.88x in 2020 to 2.32x in 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2022, the rent cover profile (excluding central cost recharges (other than for maintenance costs) and before onerous provision releases) of our 560 UK hotels run under leases and open for at least twelve months was as follows: five hotels had rent cover of less than 1.0x (including two hotels in the Aberdeen market), 34 hotels had rent cover of 1.0x to 1.5x, 100 hotels had rent cover ----- of 1.5x to 2.0x and 421 hotels had rent cover of more than 2.0x. The majority of our leases also have favorable extension rights and the average remaining term on our UK leases, excluding renewal rights and after giving effect to the LXI Re-gear that was completed in January 2023, was approximately 18 years as of December 31, 2022. The rent reviews for the leases across our estate are staggered over a five-year period to help smooth dramatic inflation increases. As a result of our tight cost control and low upfront capital expenditures on our leasehold properties, we had an EBITDA (adjusted) Margin of 23.4% in the year ended December 31, 2022, notwithstanding subdued UK hotel market growth and significant cost increases associated with wage cost growth that exceeded inflation. Our EBITDAR (adjusted) margins have also increased from 46.0% in the year ended December 31, 2018 to 49.2% in the year ended December 31, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Comprehensive sustainability plan integrated into wider strategy
Subsubsection Text: We place a strong emphasis on safety and security, the environment, and our social responsibilities. Following extensive consultation with a wide range of stakeholders, we developed a comprehensive “Better Future” sustainability plan, which was launched in 2022. The plan will help us to improve focus and performance, and to share that progress transparently with our stakeholders. We firmly believe that sustainability has a critically important role to play in shaping the future of our business. For that reason, our Better Future sustainability plan is closely aligned with our mission, to provide affordable travel for everyone and integrated with our wider business strategy. Our Better Future plan is predicated on valuing our colleagues, customers and planet, and is underpinned by three pillars: (1) _Inclusive_ _— ensuring Travelodge is accessible, inclusive, and affordable to its colleagues and customers; (2) Caring _— creating a safe and healthy environment for our colleagues and customers, and ensuring their_ wellbeing; and (3) Conscious _— being conscious of the waste we produce, the energy and resources we consume, and our carbon emissions. In line with our Better Future plan, we implemented a number of energy reduction projects in 2022. To date, we have already generated an estimated annual reduction of 24 GWh through the installation of LED lighting in most of our hotels. We also installed smart heating and cooling controls at 133 of our hotels, bringing the total across the estate to 260 hotels. These controls reduce our heating electricity consumption by approximately 45% on average per hotel. Given new technology is also important to delivering our wider business plan, we now have air to water heat pump systems installed in five new hotels and plan to replace existing electric immersion hot water systems with air to water heat pump systems in two of our existing hotels in Carlisle and Ilford in 2023. This will enable us to test and understand the challenges of retrofitting these at existing hotels and to potentially implement a wider plan of replacements of other electric immersion hot water systems within our existing estate starting in 2024. Our goal is to become a net-zero business by 2050, including measuring and reducing our indirect scope 3 emissions. As part of our Better Future plan, we intend to become a net zero operator by 2050 for our direct emissions. We plan to achieve this through a general reduction of net energy consumption by leveraging technology such as efficient LED lighting in both common areas and guestrooms, smart heating and cooling controls, solar panels and replacing old, inefficient, electrically powered boilers for hot water, with new technology such as air to water heat pumps in conjunction with the decarbonization of the national grid set in UK law. We also plan to remove our need to use gas to heat water, and substitute this with other energy producing technologies. For additional information on our key performance indicators relating to these principles, see “Business—Sustainability and ESG.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Experienced management team with solid track record of delivering operational and financial improvements
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong and experienced management team, with our Chairman and Chief Executive each having extensive experience in the hospitality and other sectors. On March 16, 2023, we announced the appointment of Aidan Connolly as Chief Financial Officer, and he started in this role on April 3, 2023. ----- Mr. Connolly previously held executive positions at My Travel, Sodexo, Worldpay, Wilko and Alter Domus. Our senior management team benefits from a wide range of experience, including prior senior roles in the airline, retail and property industries. We have strong functional teams in sales and marketing, revenue management, property, IT and operations that are led by management members who have significant experience from working with major hospitality and other brands in the United Kingdom and other countries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Clear and significant opportunities for further growth
Subsubsection Text: We have identified near-term and highly actionable opportunities to unlock growth and improve the performance of our existing estate. We have begun to refurbish our entire estate over an approximately seven-year refit cycle, which we believe will enhance revenue performance and customer satisfaction. We believe we can grow our food and beverage offering by continuing to optimize our bar café performance through better aligning our offering with customer demand and by redesigning and simplifying our menu. As of December 31, 2022, we derived 36% of our food and beverage revenue from our bar café hotels. We have not advertised on television since the previous campaign ended in May 2016. We believe there is a strong strategic basis for brand building media investment to drive consideration of our brand, which will support our long-term RevPAR growth. We plan to continue to invest in numerous energy efficiency initiatives that provide long-term cost savings and support our goal to becoming a net-zero business. For example, in 2022, we installed smart temperature controls in 133 hotels and continued to benefit from the installation of smart temperature controls in 44 hotels installed in 2021. In addition, we have installed efficient LED lighting in most common areas and LED lighting is being installed in guestrooms. Under our low capital expenditure development model, when prospective hotel sites are identified, we work with the land owner and developers to agree a proposal and sign an agreement for lease. The developer then builds the hotel to our specifications and incurs the full costs of construction. Once the project is complete, we confirm that our requirements have been met. Subsequently, the developer typically sells the hotel building to a high quality institutional investor or private investor. We then begin operations and pay rent. We are typically responsible for all ongoing maintenance capital expenditure, which is primarily comprised of stamp duty and legal fees. We believe we can continue to use this model to grow our business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our key credit strengths include the following:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Location: Extend Our Hotel Network and Strengthen Our Portfolio
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2022, we operated 45,761 rooms in 595 hotels under the Travelodge brand across the United Kingdom, Ireland and Spain. We aim to open hotels across the United Kingdom, Spain and potentially in other countries with sustainable low-cost demand. These locations include city centers, large towns and suburban markets, year-round leisure destinations, business parks and critical transport hubs. In the next few years, we plan to return to our normal hotel opening rate of 15 to 20 each year as market conditions improve. As of December 31, 2022, we had a secured pipeline of more than 22 new hotels and more than 2,100 rooms. We expect to open eight hotels and approximately 600 rooms in 2023, and we intend to continue to explore opportunities to expand our hotel portfolio beyond our secured pipeline. We have the option to expand our operations in Ireland under our master franchise agreement. In addition, we believe expansion opportunities exist in Spain under our existing development model. In the UK, we have an in-house development team, supported by external third parties, that works with local developers and landlords to identify potential opportunities for new hotels. In addition, we use independent third-party hotel consultants to identify future potential locations suitable for our hotels in the UK and Spain. As part of our expansion strategy, we are targeting another 300 potential hotel locations across the UK that would be suitable for a Travelodge hotels. Based on ----- our track record of new openings to date, we are confident that we can continue our expansion in the UK and internationally. Furthermore, while we don’t currently utilize a freehold model, we believe that a freehold model could present opportunities for growth as a largely untapped strategy, with the total capital requirement limited by the potential use of sale and leaseback transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Price: Offer Attractive Prices Supported by Predictive Data and Low-Cost Operations
Subsubsection Text: We aim to offer attractive prices using what we believe is a best in class yield management system and applying predictive analytics tools. Our price setting system uses data analysis to forecast demand, set pricing levels and monitor our rate of sale and our competitors’ pricing. Using exception reporting, our revenue team then adjusts the price points for each hotel individually where appropriate to optimize RevPAR, based on demand and competition. Our rates are updated three times per day and vary depending on hotel, room type, rate type, and stay date. We adjust our pricing to improve our RevPAR by aiming to strike the optimal balance between rate and occupancy. In the year ended December 31, 2022, over 84% of our bookings were made online through our websites. Digital sales channels are important to the growth of our business and we have already made significant changes to strengthen our presence, increasing website conversion and digital customer acquisition effectiveness. We continue to advance our digital strategy and evolve our customer targeting approach. This strategy is supported by a focus on maintaining low-cost operations through ongoing analysis of customer insight and optimizing key operational processes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Quality: Maintain Physical Asset Quality, Deliver Operational Consistency and Improve the Digital Journey
Subsubsection Text: We intend to further enhance our positioning as a distinctive brand by continuing to pursue initiatives which enhance our offer. In early 2022, we launched a new design, transforming the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés. We aim to continue our drive to improve the consistency of our customers’ experience. Our central operations team uses regular guest feedback to identify priority areas for operational change and we develop standardized processes for key areas within the hotel that directly affect the customer experience, such as room cleaning and breakfast service. We have also deployed a standard training program for our employees at each of our hotels which focuses on customer service and problem resolution, and we offer additional management development training for hotel managers. We have also continued to invest in automation tasks with our Perfect Stay mobile application, which we upgraded in 2020, and energy efficiency measures in our hotels. In 2021, we brought a significant proportion of the remaining out-sourced maintenance activity in-house, driving increased efficiency. We continue to selectively outsource certain functions and services where greater service levels or opportunities to reduce costs are available, including certain complex maintenance work, certain aspects of information technology management and telephone bookings and support. We have implemented significant improvements to our online platform to enhance the booking experience for our business customers. These include our Travelodge Business and Travelodge Business Pay products designed with small and medium enterprises in mind but which also offer noteworthy efficiencies and benefits for larger companies. These products include a dedicated website for businesses, detailed reporting functionality to enable customers to manage their bookings and travel spend with greater ease, as well as a simplified and improved booking journey which also offers a discount on our most flexible rates. Additionally, we have partnered with a third-party provider to offer Travelodge Business Pay, an interest-free credit facility for our business customers. We aim to continue to strengthen our digital marketing activity, with targeted customer offers and buying of key search terms, appropriate digital display advertising and presence in appropriate meta-search engines. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Travelodge’s mission is to provide affordable travel for everyone and we aim to offer our customers the right balance of location, price and quality to suit their travel needs. We are pursuing the following strategies to achieve this goal:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Travelodge brand was launched in the United Kingdom in 1985 as a division of Forte Hotels. Initially, Travelodge hotels were partnered with Little Chef restaurants, with the two frequently located on the same site, and the brand was known as Forte Travelodge. The first Travelodge hotel was opened in Barton-under-Needwood in the United Kingdom in 1985. In 2003, we began our international expansion, opening our first hotel in Spain and creating our master franchise for Ireland. In 2012, we underwent a restructuring of our operations and refinancing of our debt through a scheme of arrangement, and were acquired by the Sponsor, funds advised by Avenue Europe International Management, L.P. and sub-advised by Avenue Europe Management, LLP (“Avenue Capital”) and ELQ Investors VIII Limited, a wholly owned indirect subsidiary of Goldman Sachs Group Holdings (UK) Limited (“GS Sponsor”). In 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, we implemented a comprehensive recovery plan. This included new funding from the Sponsor, Avenue Capital and GS Sponsor, as well as funding from other sources, and the implementation of the CVA, which provided temporary rent reductions through the end of 2021. The CVA completed on January 19, 2023. The Sponsor acquired all the equity interests held by Avenue Capital and GS Sponsor in December 2022 and March 2023, respectively. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2022, we estimate that we attracted approximately 21 million customers over our portfolio of 595 hotels in the United Kingdom, Ireland and Spain.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As the second largest hotel brand in the United Kingdom, we have a large portfolio of hotels offering quality, affordable guest rooms across the United Kingdom and in Ireland and Spain. We operate multiple room formats across our hotels, namely our core standard rooms (43,442 in 595 hotels as of December 31, 2022), which include twin, family and accessible rooms, and our “premium economy” SuperRooms (2,319 in 64 hotels across the United Kingdom and Ireland as of December 31, 2022). In early 2022, we launched a new design, which includes a series of non-capital intensive enhancements to transform the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés based on market feedback from extensive customer research. The new design seeks to drive higher demand and rate premiums by delivering a warmer and more welcoming environment with updated room features, including blackout curtains, USB charging points by the bed, a comfortable armchair in which to relax and an upgraded bathroom. Our new design also delivers a new style bar café in our bar café hotels, offering a more flexible environment in which to eat, relax or work. In 2022, we upgraded 64 hotels and over 6,000 rooms (approximately 14% of the room estate) with our new design, with positive commercial and customer feedback, and we plan to upgrade over 4,000 rooms (approximately 10% of the room estate) in 2023. We plan to refurbish our entire estate over an approximately seven-year refit cycle. In addition, we continue to optimize our operating model by introducing technology to simplify, standardize and automate, including our investments in robot vacuums across our estate, which has helped to reduce the physical demands of the job for our team members, lower our energy consumption and deliver cost efficiencies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Almost all of our portfolio of hotels is in the United Kingdom. As of December 31, 2022, we operated 579 hotels with 43,914 rooms (or 96% of our total rooms) in the United Kingdom (excluding Northern Ireland). Our hotels offer our customers standardized and comfortable en-suite guest rooms which provide a clean look and feel. Typically, our rooms are between 15 and 21 square meters in size and contain our king-size Travelodge “Dreamer” bed. Larger rooms provide guests with one or two additional pull-out beds, depending on the size of the room. Each room has our branded curtains, artwork and bed runner and offers open hanging and shelf storage space. Additionally, rooms contain a flat screen TV. Our rooms are furnished with one or two chairs, depending on the room size, a desk and a panel heater or ----- radiator. Each room is equipped with a shower, and many also have baths. Free shower gel and hand soap are provided. In 2017, we launched our “premium economy” room type, SuperRooms, which offers additional features, including a coffee machine, rain shower and choice of pillow, as well as inroom hairdryer, iron and ironing board. For the year ended December 31, 2022, we operated 2,319 SuperRooms in 64 hotels across the United Kingdom and Ireland. In early 2022, we launched a new design, transforming the look and feel of our hotels, rooms and bar cafés, based on learnings from previous trials and extensive customer research. In 2022, we upgraded 64 hotels and over 6,000 rooms (approximately 14% of the room estate) with our new design, with positive commercial and customer feedback, and we plan to upgrade over 4,000 rooms (approximately 10% of the room estate) in 2023. Our customer base is well-diversified. As of December 31, 2022, we estimate that approximately half of our customers were business guests and half were leisure guests. Geographically, our hotels are welldistributed throughout the United Kingdom, with a concentration in high-density areas like London.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We categorize our hotels into five clusters: - London: hotels located in Central London and Greater London. - Provincial/regional: hotels in the United Kingdom outside of London. - Spain: hotels we operate in Spain. - Ireland: hotels operated under our franchise model in Ireland. - Management contracts: hotels owned by independent landlords but operated by us under management contracts. Below is a discussion of our hotel portfolio by cluster. _London_ As of December 31, 2022, we had 79 hotels with 9,888 rooms in London, representing 23% of our total hotel offering in the United Kingdom by number of rooms. Our London hotels are located throughout the city, with a high concentration in the city center and an even distribution throughout the suburbs. Generally, each London hotel has more than 100 rooms, with a bar café and limited or no parking facilities in central London and greater parking provision in greater London. Our London hotels generated £270.7 million of revenue (29.8% of our total revenue) and £98.0 million of EBITDA (adjusted) in the twelve months ended December 31, 2022. The average occupancy rate in our London hotels over the same period was 84.5%, and the average rate charged per room was £84.96, giving a RevPAR of £71.77. _Regional_ As of December 31, 2022, we had 500 hotels with 34,026 rooms located outside of London and across the United Kingdom, representing 77% of our total UK hotel offering. Generally, each regional hotel has more than 65 rooms and a parking lot. As of December 31, 2022, 32% of our regional hotels had a bar café. Our regional hotels, excluding those operated under management contract, generated £622.2 million of revenue (68.3% of total revenue) and £176.3 million of EBITDA (adjusted) in the twelve months ended December 31, 2022. The average occupancy rate in these hotels over the same period was 80.9%, and the average rate charged per room was £58.24, giving a RevPAR of £47.13. ----- Of the 500 hotels located in regional areas, we operate 10 under management contracts and own one, as of December 31, 2022. The remaining 489 hotels are operated under leases. See “—Management _Contracts.” Spain_ As of December 31, 2022, we operated five hotels with 621 rooms in Barcelona, Madrid and Valencia, Spain. In early 2023, we opened a new hotel in Madrid, which was the first opening in Spain in over ten years. We also have an office in Madrid which provides local operational support and financial control. Our Spanish hotels generated £14.7 million of revenue and £3.2 million of EBITDA (adjusted) in the twelve months ended December 31, 2022. The average occupancy rate in the hotels over the same period was 84.1%, and the average rate charged per room was €81.42, giving a RevPAR of €68.48. _Ireland_ As of December 31, 2022, we had 11 Travelodge hotels with 1,226 rooms in operation in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland pursuant to a franchise agreement with Smorgs ROI Management Limited, as franchisee (“Smorgs”), and guaranteed by a large hotel management company in Ireland. The franchise agreement was entered into in 2016 for a term to 2034. We receive income through monthly franchise fees from Smorgs, equal to £1.6 million of EBITDA (adjusted) in the twelve months ended December 31, 2022. An additional booking fee is payable for each customer. Five hotels with 802 rooms are located in Dublin, and the rest of the hotels are in Belfast, Cork, Derry, Galway, Limerick and Waterford. _Management Contracts_ As of December 31, 2022, we operated ten hotels in the United Kingdom under management contracts pursuant to which we operate the hotels but do not hold a leasehold interest in the properties. These management agreements arose because the ten sites in question were sites which we considered would not be commercially viable for us to operate with a full leasehold interest, but which could be successfully run using shorter-term, lower-cost management agreements. Eight of these hotels are roadside sites which are operated under management agreements with Moto Hospitality Limited, four of which are due to expire in 2027 and four of which are due to expire in 2031. The remaining two sites are operated under management agreements with various third parties, which will expire in 2023 and 2029, respectively. We are currently negotiating extensions for these management agreements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have an onsite bar café at approximately 210 of our larger hotels in the United Kingdom. Our bar cafés serve breakfast at an affordable price and offer cooked and continental breakfasts. In our hotels that do not have a bar café, we serve pre-packed breakfast boxes to take away. Most of our bar cafés also serve lunch and dinner. Our menu offering includes a range of popular meals, including freshlymade and authentic stone-baked pizza, salads, burgers and desserts. We also offer value-driven “meal deals” and a children’s dinner menu.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Most of our Travelodge hotels are operated under two types of operating models. The vast majority of our hotels in the United Kingdom and Spain are operated by us under a leasehold model, while our Irish hotels are operated under a franchise agreement with Smorgs. In addition, we operate one hotel under a freehold model and ten hotels under management contracts. ----- _Leasehold Model_ As of December 31, 2022, we held leases for 568 hotels in the United Kingdom and five hotels in Spain. As of December 31, 2022, after giving effect to the LXI Re-gear, the average remaining term on our leases, excluding renewal rights, was 17.7 years in the United Kingdom and 9.9 years in Spain. Most of our leases are standard triple net leases with typical commercial terms and an average term of 25 years (although properties in city centers and London are occasionally operated on terms of 35 years or longer). Most of our leases are subject to standard, five-yearly and upwards-only rent reviews, indexed against the RPI, RPIX or CPI, while only a small number of our leases are subject to open market rent reviews. Some of these leases have caps and collars, usually at 1% and 4%, respectively. Three of our leases are subject to annual, upwards-only rent reviews indexed against the RPI. Under most of these leases, we have a contractual or statutory right to renew beyond the initial term, usually for a further 25 years. By leasing our properties, we avoid many of the high costs associated with the acquisition and development of the land on which our properties are situated, and we incur lower upfront capital expenditure costs. _LXI Re-gear_ In December 2022, we announced an agreement with LXI REIT plc (the “LXI Re-gear”), the Group’s largest landlord, for a lease re-gear on 122 hotels, which they acquired as part of their acquisition of Secure Income REIT in July 2022. In January 2023, we completed the LXI Re-gear for 97 of our hotels. We expect to re-gear leases for an additional 25 hotels, subject to obtaining superior landlord consent, in the second quarter of 2023. As part of the LXI Re-gear, rent reviews moved to a CPI + 0.5% per annum basis with caps and collars (4% per annum and 1% per annum, respectively) replacing the previously uncapped and uncollared RPI rent reviews. The unexpired lease terms on 97 hotels were extended by a weighted average of nine years, and the parties agreed to a “rent-smoothing” of the hotels on a site-by-site basis to ensure that each hotel has a robust stand-alone Rent Cover. We also took the opportunity to agree “green lease” provisions, including sharing of energy, water, recycling and waste data and cooperation on the environmental, social and governance strategies of the landlord and tenant. _Franchise Model_ All of our Irish hotels are operated under a master franchise agreement with Smorgs, and guaranteed by a large hotel management company in Ireland. The agreement expires in 2034 and requires Smorgs to pay a franchise fee, as well as a booking fee per customer reservation, and to comply with certain operational requirements. Smorgs receives brand, revenue management and operational guidance from us, and has the benefit of certain guarantees which we provide to landlords. As part of our strategy to expand our hotel portfolio, we may consider adapting this master franchise agreement such that it can be used in new jurisdictions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We set the prices for all our hotels centrally, using a dedicated pricing and revenue management team. This team determines our pricing strategy by hotel according to product quality, demand and competition. Our pricing strategy is supported by our revenue management system, which uses data analysis to forecast occupancy, optimize prices using information such as our rate of sale and our competitors’ rates. Our centralized revenue management team, consisting of approximately 30 people, processes the information provided by our revenue management system and adjusts the price points for each hotel individually to optimize RevPAR. We completed a major revenue management system upgrade in 2019, which in conjunction with investments in our data and analytics capability, has enhanced our strong performance after the COVID-19 pandemic. Our rates are updated up to 3 times ----- per day as internal and external factors change. We have a dedicated events team to monitor key events, such as large attendance concerts, sports events and cultural events, to set and adjust event specific pricing based on forecast demand. Our centralized team uses high-quality reporting, benchmarking and data analytics to monitor performance and adjust pricing in real time to further optimize the prices charged. Our RGI grew from 92 in January 2020 to 103 in December 2022, which indicates that our growth outpaced the growth of the market during this period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended December 31, 2022, we opened six new hotels (including London Docklands Central, which replaced an existing hotel, and the Irish franchise in Dublin City Center), largely consisting of new hotels built especially for Travelodge and existing buildings or hotels converted into Travelodge hotels. We use one of the following three strategies in developing new hotels: - We enter into partnerships with a range of landlords and developers including major institutions and property companies as well as local developers and high net worth individuals who are specialists in their local area. Travelodge determines the build specifications and we enter into an agreement for a lease with the landlord, which grants the lease once development works are completed. This is the most common type of acquisition that we carry out. Usually, the agreement for a lease is conditional upon factors such as site acquisition, financing, vacant possession, and the granting of planning permission. Under this type of development, the majority of the capital spend is for the account of the developer but internal costs, such as fees and stamp duty, are monitored and regularly reported by our finance team; - We enter into a forward-funded development whereby Travelodge carries out the development works, funded by a third party; or - We acquire hotels by purchasing going concerns. In these circumstances, the terms of the purchase vary greatly from deal to deal. However, in general, the transaction is structured so that we enter into an agreement with the estate owner and/or the landlord and any existing operator. In this scenario, we acquire certain elements of the business and assets of the existing operator and a leasehold interest in the hotel. We then subsequently re-brand and refurbish the hotel as a Travelodge hotel. - We from time-to-time close certain of our individual hotels. In 2022, 2021 and 2020, we closed three, four and 19 hotels, respectively. The comparatively large amount of hotel closures in 2020 was the result of the implementation of the CVA during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Developed Properties_ When deciding on new sites, we review the demographics, business and employment data of proposed locations. We also review existing and proposed transportation links, the importance of the proposed site for national and international tourism and the proximity to universities, hospitals and military bases. Based on this approach, we have identified a significant number of viable sites for further consideration, some of which are in our current pipeline. _Pipeline Developments_ As of December 31, 2022, we had entered into agreements to operate upwards of 22 new hotels with more than 2,100 rooms (our “secured pipeline”), of which we expect to open eight hotels in 2023. We currently envisage spending approximately £5 million on development costs in 2023 in light of new ----- hotel openings. In the next few years, we plan to return to our normal hotel opening rate of 15 to 20 each year as market conditions improve. We develop our secured pipeline through a network of employed and freelance development managers who search for opportunities. Once an eligible project has been identified on the basis of our investment model, our development managers enter into initial discussions with the developers and begin to record and monitor the development project in our database. As the discussions advance, we enter into term sheets which set out the basic principles of a potential development, and relevant committee approvals and planning permissions are sought. When certain conditions are satisfied, we execute a formal lease agreement and the property becomes part of our “secured pipeline.” A few conditions remain until the project is classified unconditional. The developer then builds the property to our specification using its own funds. Our costs are typically limited to certain advisory and planning fees. _List of Newly-Opened UK Leased Hotels_ Below is a table showing the location, rooms and opening date of all hotels opened since January 1, 2020:

Subsubsection Text: London Beckton 113 January 23, 2020 Gosport 70 January 29, 2020 Macclesfield Central 68 January 30, 2020 Sittingbourne 63 February 27, 2020 Workington 78 March 8, 2020 Portsmouth City Center 152 April 12, 2020 London Stockley Park 81 July 9, 2020 Maldon 60 July 27, 2020 Elgin 61 August 13, 2020 London Mile End 80 September 21, 2020 Leicester City Center 67 March 3, 2021 Bristol Emersons Green 90 March 15, 2021 Kendal Town Center 69 March 22, 2021 Newark-on-Trent 66 March 22, 2021 Rochdale 66 March 22, 2021 Boston 56 March 29, 2021 St Albans City Center 130 April 19, 2021 Faringdon Oxfordshire 74 April 19, 2021 Bristol Avonmouth 81 April 19, 2021 Sandwich 75 May 24, 2021 Poole North 81 July 4, 2021 London Manor House 143 July 22, 2021 Witney 63 August 3, 2021 London Elephant & Castle 140 August 16, 2021 Mansfield Town Center 63 December 2, 2021 Newcastle Cobalt Business Park 80 December 14, 2021 Walton-on-Thames Central 72 December 22, 2021 Braintree 70 January 27, 2022 London Wimbledon Central 177 March 11, 2022 London Lewisham 127 March 15, 2022 Hexham 69 June 13, 2022 London Docklands Central 350 June 20, 2022 Madrid Coslada Aeropuerto 78 February 23, 2023 ----- In 2022 we carried out a review of our new hotel construction specification and have identified opportunities to make changes. These changes have resulted in a policy that new Travelodge hotels will achieve A rated EPC and a BREEAM performance level of at least Very Good in the future. We expect to introduce the amended specification in 2023. Given the lead time from agreeing a lease to the opening of our hotels is typically around 18-24 months, this will ensure that hotels opening from 2026 onwards should achieve these standards.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We focus on using products that have sustainable credentials, require as little CO2 as possible to make and generate as little waste to landfill as possible for the cyclical refurbishment of our hotels. We also aim to reuse or recycle as many of the things we replace in this process as possible. During our extensive 2022 refurbishment program, our partner contractors made significant progress in reducing waste to landfill, with 35% of projects completed without sending any waste to landfill. In 2023 we intend to continue working with our partners to make significant further reductions in waste to landfill and to further improve the reuse or recycling of items we replace in the course of a refurbishment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The majority of our maintenance jobs are completed in-house through our dedicated maintenance team, which was formed in 2011 and consisted of more than 244 people as of December 31, 2022. We continue to outsource specialist services, such as boiler and elevator maintenance and repair work.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We conduct our sales through various channels. For the year ended December 31, 2022, approximately 90% of our bookings were made through direct bookings, including approximately 80% made through our websites and approximately 10% through walk-ins, call centers and Groups. We have limited reliance on third-party brokers and OTAs (which accounted for approximately 1% of our UK room booking revenue in 2022). Since 2016, we have offered Travelodge business memberships to our business customers. We also continue to attract rising numbers of business customers in line with our range of locations, continued focus on attractive pricing and enhanced quality levels, including our new SuperRooms in major cities in the UK. Business membership is free of charge and allows customers to benefit from certain preferential services such as a dedicated account manager and discounts on flexible rate bookings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the midscale and economy sector of the hotel market (as defined by STR) and are positioned as a budget operator, offering standardized, modern guest rooms at affordable prices to both business and leisure customers. Our purpose is to provide affordable travel for everyone and we aim to offer our customers the right balance of location, price and quality for their travel needs. As of December 31, 2022, demand and customers were spread across many unrelated sectors such as leisure, blue collar and white collar, and we estimate that approximately half of our customers were business guests and half were leisure guests.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to certain legal requirements and potential liabilities under various laws and regulations, including the regulations for environmental impact, hazardous waste and prevention and control for the contamination of water, air and soil. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry— _Failure to comply with environmental, health and safety laws and regulations may result in a material adverse effect on our business.”_ ----- We believe that we hold robust internal environmental management systems designed to ensure our hotels comply with current regulations and can control potential hazards that could damage the environment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The majority of our IT services are centralized, standard services provided by third parties (via either software as a service or similar outsourced models). Our websites and core internal Travelodge systems are hosted by third parties. Our customers can use our mobile application to search for and book rooms. Our price setting system determines the prices we charge for our rooms. This yield management system controls opening and closing prices according to demand and price sensitivity. See “Principal Business _Activities—Price Management.” The other IT services we use are generally standard package solutions,_ with the exception of our website which is a combination of standard and bespoke technology. We plan to continue to review and invest in our IT systems and processes. _Data Security and Customer Privacy_ We are committed to ensuring that all personal data, relating to both our customers and employees, is safely held and is used in an ethical manner. We hold our key supply chain to stringent auditable data security standards prior to contract start or upon renewal based on the risk they present to us, (predominantly ISO27001 and NIST), and data processing agreements which cover all aspects of privacy including subject rights, transfer legality, information security controls, sub-processing and applicable standards. We also have a Data Protection Officer to arbitrate on behalf of our customers and employees. We believe this is important, despite not being a legal requirement following a change of guidance in 2022, because it offers impartial protection to our customers and staff should data incidents arise. We only collect and maintain sensitive personal information data where it is strictly necessary for protection of life, such as for health and safety reasons, to maintain good employment practices or for other lawful reasons. Such usages are subject to mandatory privacy assessment. We originally selected the Centre for Internet Security (CIS) Critical Controls Framework to start benchmarking our cyber security and drive the cyber security maturity of the organization. This was done via self-assessment and has served the organization well in getting our maturity to the level it currently is, on a par with our industry peers. We have recently transitioned our Information Security audit framework from the CIS framework to the globally recognized National Institute of Standards and Technology (“NIST”) CyberSecurity Framework. From 2023, this NIST control framework will be externally audited by a specialist agency to provide wider assurance and consistency. This transition reflects the progress we have made in previous years and will enable our security and compliance programs to stay aligned with industry best practices moving forward. We also conduct a wide array of employee training and awareness programs, as well as scheduled and ad hoc technical security testing using a range of security tooling and independent third party specialists, alongside a responsible disclosure program. We have an externally facing policy, available on our website, which provides instruction to external cyber testers on how to disclose cyber issues they may be aware of in relation to our website and other assets in an ethical manner. Issues raised are tracked internally up to resolution. We maintain, train and support data privacy champions in each of our business functions, whose role is to ensure ongoing compliance with ethical business practices with regard to our customer and employee data. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We own the rights to the Travelodge name or brandmarks in more than 50 countries around the world, with rights pending or published in three additional countries. We have an EU-wide registration that covers all EU Member States. In addition, we own the right to the “sleeping face” logo in various territories, including in certain locations where we do not own the Travelodge name due to the name rights having been secured by other businesses. We understand that there are three further operators of the Travelodge name in other regions of the world who are not connected with our Group: one based in North America, which operates and owns the rights in the USA and Canada, one based in Australasia, which operates in Australia and New Zealand and one based in Asia which owns the rights to the Travelodge name in a number of territories in Asia, including Hong Kong, Malaysia, Pakistan and Singapore.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Set forth below are the average number and total number of persons employed for the year ended December 31, 2022:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: As of December 31, 2022 Average number of full time equivalent persons employed ....................................** **7,907

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Total number of persons employed as of December 31, 2022 .................................** **12,287
Subsubsection Text: thereof: UK ............................................................................................................_ 12,206 thereof: International ............................................................................................._ 81 Our total number of employees fluctuates during the year, as we adjust roles and hours according to the needs of the business and occupancy levels in the hotels. The majority of employees are employed on hourly contracts, with flexible working hours. We offer the over 23 year old National Living Wage to staff of all ages. Since April 6, 2017, we are required to pay an apprenticeship levy of 0.5% on our wages bill to help fund training for apprenticeships in the United Kingdom. The majority of employees are employed within the hotels. We have a central support office which serves as the home office for the direct salesforce and is the base for corporate support functions and our customer services team. We employ a limited number of agency staff to work in our head office and in our operations. We also occasionally employ a number of contractors time to provide assistance on projects and interim specialist support. We operate an in-house development program called Aspire through which our employees can strengthen their professional development and obtain formal hospitality industry qualifications through apprenticeships. We are subject to laws and regulations relating to equality, in particular to compliance with regulations affecting “protected categories” such as gender, race, religious affiliation and sexual orientation. See “—Legal Proceedings and Disputes” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—We are subject to laws governing our relationship with hotel employees, such as minimum wage requirements, overtime, working conditions and work permit regulations.”_ In our Irish hotels, our franchisees employ their own staff and management. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have two pension schemes: a Scottish Widows Group pension plan for salaried staff who are paid monthly, and a NEST pension plan for staff who are paid by the hour on a four-weekly basis. Both are defined contribution schemes. Employees are automatically enrolled in one of these schemes at the start of the month following completion of two months’ service. Other than increases in contributions required by law, we do not expect significant pension liabilities going forward.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We place a strong emphasis on safety and security, the environment, and our social responsibilities. Following extensive consultation with a wide range of stakeholders, we developed a comprehensive sustainability plan, “Better Future,” designed to mark a step-change in our sustainability agenda. The plan will help us to both improve focus and performance, and to share that progress transparently with our stakeholders. We firmly believe that sustainability has a critically important role to play in shaping the future of our business. For that reason, our sustainability plan “Better Future” is closely aligned with our goal of providing affordable travel for everyone and integrated with our wider business strategy. _Our “Better Future” sustainability plan_ Valuing our employees, customers and planet is the vision that underpins the three pillars of our sustainability plan. 1. _Inclusive: Ensuring Travelodge is accessible, inclusive, and affordable to its employees and customers. 2. _Caring: Creating a safe and healthy environment for our employees and customers, and ensuring their wellbeing. 3. _Conscious: Being conscious of the waste we produce, the energy and resources we consume, and our carbon emissions. ----- _Diversity_ We are committed to creating an inclusive workplace, one which provides opportunities to learn more and earn more and one where everyone can be their true self and belong. We attach great importance to our inclusion of a diverse range of people throughout all areas of our business We monitor the diversity of our existing workforce in order to uphold a culture of equality, diversity and inclusion. We have both an equality and diversity policy and a trans inclusion policy in place. We use our diversity data to understand the makeup of our workforce and whether it is representative of both the wider UK society and geographical areas. This helps us to focus our attention on the areas where improvement is needed and create action plans to address these. Our focus on equality and diversity has helped us to reach a position where around 63% of our hotel managers are women. We are ahead of the new target of 40% female representation for diversity in senior leadership roles, as set out by the Hampton-Alexander review for FTSE 350 companies. 48% of our Senior Leadership team are women, as are 57% of our operating board, however, we continue to have targets in place to remain focused on gender balance. We operate a number of equality and diversity groups covering topics such as gender, ethnicity, LGBTQ+ and disability. Each group has an operating board sponsor as well as members from the senior leadership team. The groups were formed in 2022, recognizing that a successful ED&I agenda must be driven by the most senior people in the company. _Environmental_ Our goal is to become a net-zero business by 2050, including measuring and reducing our indirect scope 3 emissions. Having now agreed our plan for direct scope 1 and 2 emissions and the process to understand indirect scope 3 emissions, in the coming year we will set out to deliver this plan to target. This will include the continued installation of smart heating and cooling controls within our hotels, testing the ability to retrofit air source heat pump technology into a trial set of hotels and revising our new build and refurbishment specifications to reflect the strategic importance of sustainability. We also expect to conclude the initial measurement of our indirect scope 3 emissions. Through the implementation of this plan, we expect to meet our target to reduce our electricity consumption by 13% by the end of 2023, compared with a 2017 baseline. ----- The UK government has set in law that the UK will be net-zero by 2050, and we expect that legislation will evolve in the coming decades to require businesses and individuals/consumers to move away from gas consumption. For example, by 2025, all new homes will be banned from installing gas and oil boilers and will instead be heated by low-carbon alternatives. We intend to assess our indirect scope 3 emissions during 2023 and to submit or consolidate direct and indirect plans by the end of 2023. Our direct carbon footprint for 2022 was 41,270 tons (2021: 39,922 tons) of carbon dioxide and equivalent gases (CO2e), with an intensity of 45.4 tons (2021: 71.3 tons) of CO2e per million pound of turnover and 3.1 tons (2021: 4.0 tons) of CO2e per 1,000 nights sold. Although overall we used 10% more energy in 2022 versus 2021, our intensity metrics decreased because: - we have continued to roll out smart heating cooling controls during 2022 to 133 hotels and benefited from the annualization of a further 44 hotels completed in 2021; - generally, 2022 was a warmer year than 2021, requiring less energy to heat our hotels, particularly in quarter one and four; and - we were more occupied in our hotels and had more sleepers staying with us, which inherently keeps our hotels warmer and therefore requires less energy to maintain similar heating levels. We have reported on all of the emission sources which we deem ourselves to be responsible for, as required under the Companies Act 2006 (Strategic Report and Directors Report) Regulations 2013. These sources fall within our operations control and financial boundaries and include emissions from manufacturing, retail and distribution sites and the operation of our distribution fleet.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
